title: Best One-Day Internet IPOs: Stocks
subhead: Twitter's first day return of 73% was among the top performing Internet IPOs since 2011
overview: Bloomberg ranked U.S. Internet initial public offerings since January 1, 2011, based on their total returns after one day of trading.
methodology: Only offerings of at least $75 million were included. Total returns for one week, one month and through November 7, 2013, were provided for comparison. Returns for offerings with more than one year of pricing data were annualized.

title: Best One-Week Internet IPOs: Stocks
subhead: Twitter's first week return of 72% was among the top performing Internet IPOs since 2011
overview: Bloomberg ranked U.S. Internet initial public offerings since January 1, 2011, based on their total returns after one week of trading.
methodology: Only offerings of at least $75 million were included. Total returns for one day, one month and through November 14, 2013, were provided for comparison. Returns for offerings with more than one year of pricing data were annualized.

title: Biggest Decreases in Gold Stockpiles: Countries
subhead: Switzerland has had the biggest decrease in gold reserves
overview: Bloomberg ranked countries based on the change in their central bank gold reserves as a result of sales from December 1993 to June 2013.
methodology: The original unit of measure was millions of troy ounces, which were converted to metric tons.

title: Biggest Increases in Gold Stockpiles: Countries
subhead: Russia has had the greatest 20-year increase in gold reserves
overview: Bloomberg ranked countries based on the change in their central bank gold reserves as a result of sales from December 1993 to June 2013.
methodology: The original unit of measure was millions of troy ounces, which were converted to metric tons.

title: Most Affordable Among the Most Expensive: Colleges
subhead: Harvard and Vassar offer the best grant aid among the priciest colleges in the U.S.
overview: Bloomberg ranked the 100 most expensive colleges and universities in the U.S. based on two equally weighted criteria: the percentage of full-time first-time undergraduates receiving federal, state, local or institutional grant aid and the average amount of aid received.
methodology: The percentage of students receiving aid was calculated by dividing the number of full-time first-time undergraduates receiving aid by the total number of full-time first-time degree/certificate-seeking undergraduates. The full or "sticker" price is the total annual price for students living on campus: tuition and fees plus estimated nontuition expenses such as room and board, books and supplies, transportation and personal expenses. The average net price for students getting financial aid is total cost minus average grant aid, and is based on the percentage of students receiving grant and scholarship aid. Grant aid includes students living on and off campus. (The average net cost was calculated using a weighted housing cost.) Colleges were ranked on both criteria and the ranks were averaged then subtracted from 100 to come up with the final order. The 100 most expensive schools were drawn from a universe of 1,939 public and private not-for-profit schools of four years or more that offer broad curricula.
sources: Bloomberg; U.S. Department of Education, National Center for Education Statistics, Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System (IPEDS) 2010-2011 data from Student Financial Aid component (final release)

title: Most Assets Worldwide: Banks
subhead: China and the U.S. each have five banks among the world's 25 largest
overview: Bloomberg ranked 3,606 global banks and institutional financial services companies by their latest annual total assets and identified the top 25.
methodology: Assets for HSBC Holdings, Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, Credit Agricole, Royal Bank of Scotland Group, Mizuho Financial Group, Societe Generale, Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group and UniCredit were as of June 30, 2013; all other data were as of September 30, 2013.

title: Lowest Paid with Strong Stock Performance: CEOs
subhead: Fifteen relatively low-paid CEOs who are delivering stellar performance in 2013
overview: Bloomberg ranked CEOs of companies with market caps of least $1 billion and year-to-date stock returns exceeding the S&P 500 total return of 25.5% based on their most recent total compensation.
methodology: The 15 CEOs with the lowest pay among the 942 companies that met these criteria as of October 25, 2013 were identified. All CEOs named were in their jobs for their companies' entire fiscal year and were still CEOs as of October 25, 2013. The fiscal year of Take-Two Interactive Software ended March 31, the fiscal year for Ubiquiti Networks ended June 30 and the fiscal year for Harbinger Group ended September 30, 2012. The fiscal year of all other companies ended December 31, 2012. CEOs of partnerships were excluded.

title: Most Residents Thrice Wed or More: States
subhead: Is the third time the charm? Arkansans, who have the highest 3+ marriage rate, seem to think so
overview: Bloomberg ranked the U.S. states and the District of Columbia based on the percentage of the population ages 15 years and older who have been married at least three times.
methodology: Data were rounded.

title: Biggest Drop in Debt Relative to GDP: Countries
subhead: Government debt relative to GDP is falling for many debt-laden countries except Egypt and Spain
overview: Bloomberg ranked countries based on the estimated percentage-point change in government debt as a percentage of GDP from 2013 to 2018.
methodology: Included were countries with an estimated GDP of $50 billion or more in 2013 and estimated government debt as a percentage of GDP of more than 100 percent in either 2013 or 2018.  A negative change indicates a reduction in the debt ratio.
sources: International Monetary Fund World Economic Outlook Database

title: Most Money Raised: Kickstarter Campaigns
winner: Pebble: E-Paper Watch for iPhone and Android
subhead: Sixteen Kickstarter campaigns raised more than $1M each since inception of site
overview: Bloomberg ranked Kickstarter campaigns based on the amount raised.
methodology: The ranking covers completed campaigns since kickstarter.com's inception on April 28, 2009.

title: Most Funds Raised Through Green Bonds: Issuers
winner: World Bank: International Bank for Reconstruction and Development
subhead: World Bank organizations have sold more than $5 billion of bonds to reduce greenhouse gas emissions
overview: Bloomberg ranked multilateral organizations issuing green bonds to fund clean-energy projects based on the total value of offerings.
methodology: The ranking includes only bonds that were publicly disclosed based on ratings and other announcements from data compiled by Bloomberg New Energy Finance from January 1, 2007 through October 16, 2013. Currency conversions were calculated on the date of issuance.

title: Most Common in China: Surnames
subhead: Nearly 7% of the Chinese population has the surname Li (æŽ)
overview: Bloomberg ranked Chinese surnames based on the size of population sharing them.
methodology: Bloomberg Rankings annotated the basic Pinyin pronunciation for the 100 most common surnames and calculated their percentages within the entire Chinese population, which was 1.37 billion as of 2010. These 100 surnames account for over three-quarters of the entire Chinese population. Pinyin is the official system for phonic spelling of Chinese characters in mainland China.

title: Biggest Rise in Health-Care Cost Relative to Income: Countries
subhead: For every $1,000 increase in Americans'  income from 2001-2011, their health-care costs rose $291
overview: Bloomberg ranked countries based on the increase in health-care cost relative to the increase in income over 10 years.
methodology: Data from 2001 to 2011 on GDP per capita, total health expenditure and health expenditure breakdowns were analyzed. Total health expenditure, which covers preventive and curative health services, family planning, nutrition activities and emergency aid, is the sum of public and private health expenditures.  Private health expenditure includes direct household spending and private insurance. Out-of-pocket cost is part of private health cost and is direct individual outlay. Included were countries with a ten-year annualized rate of health-care cost increase that exceeded that of the GDP per capita, with current GDP per capita of at least $1,000 and with a population of at least 5 million.
sources: International Monetary Fund, World Health Organization, World Bank

title: Most Licensed Drivers 19 and Younger: States
subhead: Iowa and South Dakota lead the U.S. in percentage of youngest drivers
overview: Bloomberg ranked the U.S. states and the District of Columbia on the percentage of licensed drivers ages 19 and younger.
methodology: Data are for 2011, the most recent year available. Illinois data are for 2010.

title: Most Licensed Drivers Age 85+: States
subhead: Connecticut has more than double the percentage of 85+ licensed drivers than any other state
overview: Bloomberg ranked the U.S. states and the District of Columbia on the percentage of licensed drivers ages 85 and older.
methodology: Data are for 2011, the most recent year available. Illinois data are for 2010.

title: Biggest Five-Year Decline in Pension Funding: States
subhead: All but five states saw a decline in pension funding ratios between 2007 and 2012
overview: Bloomberg ranked states based on the percentage-point change in each state's pension funding between 2007 and 2012.
methodology: Data were obtained by the Bloomberg Municipal Data Team and the Municipal Fundamentals Team from each state's Comprehensive Annual Financial Report. Data are for individual state's respective fiscal year-ends as of the date of the publication of the CAFR.

title: Highest Salaries for Software Engineers: Companies
subhead: The base salary for software engineers at Juniper Networks is 25% higher than at Google
overview: Bloomberg ranked companies based on the average base salary for software engineers reported by employees to Glassdoor, a California-based jobs and career community, between October 1, 2012 and September 30, 2013.
methodology: Salaries for each company were based on at least 50 reports by engineers.

title: Highest Salaries for Software Engineers: U.S. Cities
subhead: West Coast software engineers earn most, though Boston, NYC and Baltimore also make the top 10
overview: Bloomberg ranked U.S. cities based on the average base salary for software engineers reported to Glassdoor, a California-based jobs and career community, between October 1, 2012 and September 30, 2013.
methodology: Salaries for each metropolitan area were based on at least 150 salary reports by software engineers. The U.S. national average is based on 33,000 software engineer salary reports submitted to Glassdoor.

title: Worst Five-Year Outlook in Europe: Countries
subhead: Mediterranean countries still have Europe's worst economic prospects; Scandinavian nations have best
overview: Bloomberg ranked EU countries, Iceland, Norway and Switzerland based on five-year forecasts for their economies.
methodology: Gini scores (a measure of income inequality) from the most recent five years of data were included, with higher inequality scores negatively affecting countries' overall scores. For each variable, the maximum and minimum values of the 31 countries were determined. Countries received a score of 0-100, calculated proportionally, based on where their scores fell between these two extremes. The four scores were then averaged for a final score. A lower final score indicates a worse economic outlook. Gini scores are from 1-100, with 1 representing perfect income equality and 100 perfect inequality. Income refers to "equivalized disposable income," according to Eurostat.

title: Top 20 Tech-Turnaround Artists: CEOs
subhead: These tech CEOs turned their stocks from laggards to outperformers
overview: Bloomberg ranked CEOs of technology companies based on the improvement of each company's stock performance from the week before its CEO's appointment was announced until October 11, 2013.
methodology: Companies were drawn from a list of the top 250 U.S. technology companies by market capitalization. The list included companies in the e-commerce, internet media and internet-based services industries, and excluded companies in the distribution, information services and payment and data processor industries. Excluded were CEOs who were founders of their companies or had  tenure of less than one year or more than 10 years as of October 11, 2013. To create this ranking, the total returns of the stocks were calculated from one week before the CEO's appointment was announced (because rumors may have been circulating) until October 11, 2013, and for the two years prior to that period. These returns were compared to the performance of the S&P 500 for the same periods and the difference in percentage points was calculated. All returns are cumulative. Only companies that underperformed the S&P 500 prior to the CEO announcement period and outperformed since that time appear on the list.

title: Harshest Future Austerity Measures: Countries
subhead: Japan may be under stimulus now, but plans for eventual withdrawal make it top-ranked for austerity
overview: Bloomberg ranked countries based on the forecast magnitude of austerity measures over the next two years.
methodology: Using the IMF's October 2013 update of its World Economic Outlook Database, austerity is measured by the percentage-point change in the general government's structural balance -- the portion of a country's budget that governments can control through tax increases and/or spending cuts (economic cycles may change the balance further) -- as a percentage of GDP. General government refers to all levels of government combined: central, state/provincial/regional and local. A negative number in the structural balance indicates a budget deficit; a positive number indicates a surplus. Changes from 2011 to 2013 were included for comparison. All countries for which data were available are included.

title: Top-Selling Born Since 1980: Artists
subhead: More than half of the 20 top-selling young artists are Asian
overview: Bloomberg ranked artists born since 1980 based on total sales-at-auctions data through September 30, 2013.
methodology: Sales included buyers' premiums. JR's identity is unconfirmed. Dash Snow died in 2009.

title: Top-Selling Born Since 1970: Artists
subhead: British graffiti mural painter Banksy is the top-selling artist born since 1970
overview: Bloomberg ranked artists born since 1970 based on total sales-at-auctions data through September 30, 2013.
methodology: Sales included buyers' premiums.

title: Highest Growth in GDP and Population: States
subhead: North Dakota and Texas lead the U.S. in economic and population growth since 2008
overview: Bloomberg ranked the U.S. states and the District of Columbia based on the percentage change in population and real GDP from 2008 to 2012.
methodology: The score is the average percentage rank of both factors. Census population estimates are as of July 1, 2008, and July 1, 2012.
sources: U.S. Bureau of Economic Analysis, U.S. Census

title: Greatest Risk of Stagflation: Countries
subhead: Cyprus, Italy and Portugal top this list of countries in danger of stagflation
overview: Bloomberg ranked countries based on their risk of stagflation.
methodology: First, the average real Gross Domestic Product change and average Consumer Price Index change was calculated for each country from 2012 to 2014. Then the Stagflation Score was determined by multiplying average real GDP change by average CPI change if the average real GDP change was negative or by dividing average real GDP change by average CPI change if the average real GDP change was positive. The lower the score, the greater the risk of stagflation. Data for Kuwait Real GDP 2012 were estimates. Data for Cyprus were provided by the European Commission.

title: Top-Grossing in U.S.: Stephen King Movies
subhead: The Green Mile is king based on box-office receipts
overview: Bloomberg ranked movies based on Stephen King novels by all-time U.S. box-office receipts.
methodology: U.S. receipts were adjusted to the estimated 2013 average ticket price of $8.16. Inflation-adjustment is mostly done by multiplying estimated admissions by the latest average ticket price. Where admissions are unavailable, adjustment is based on the average ticket price for when each movie was released (taking in to account re-releases where applicable).

title: Most Bike Lanes: U.S. Cities
subhead: Tucson leads U.S. cities in miles of on-street bike lanes
overview: Bloomberg ranked 25 U.S. cities with more than 354,000 residents based on the miles of on-street bike lanes.
methodology: Data from the 2009 American Community Survey were used for the Benchmarking Report.
sources: Alliance for Biking & Walking, Bicycling and Walking in the United States 2012 Benchmarking Report

title: Worst Gridlock: U.S. Cities
subhead: DC motorists waste 67 hours each year sitting in traffic
overview: Bloomberg ranked U.S. metropolitan areas with more than 500,000 residents based on annual hours of delays per commuter in 2012.
methodology: The cost of congestion is based on an estimated value of $16.79 for each hour of person travel and $86.81 per hour of truck time as well as the average cost of fuel in each state.
sources: Texas A&M University, Texas Transportation Institute, Urban Mobility Report 2012

title: Biggest Declines in Homeownership: States
subhead: Nevada homeownership is down 10 percentage points since 2004, the peak year for U.S. homeownership
overview: Bloomberg ranked the U.S. states and the District of Columbia based on the percentage-point change in the annual homeownership rate from 2004 to 2012.
methodology: Only occupied houses were included.
sources: U.S. Census Current Population Survey/Housing Vacancy Survey

title: Most Reliant on Nuclear Energy: Countries
subhead: Three-quarters of France's energy comes from nuclear power
overview: Bloomberg ranked countries based on nuclear power as a percentage of total energy consumption.
methodology: Each country's production of nuclear electricity is shown.

title: Highest Homeownership Rates: U.S. Cities
subhead: Grand Rapids has the highest, and L.A. the lowest, homeownership rate in the U.S.
overview: Bloomberg ranked the 75 largest metropolitan statistical areas in the U.S. based on their homeownership rate in Q2 2013, the latest data available.
methodology: The homeownership rate included only occupied houses.
sources: U.S. Census Current Population Survey/Housing Vacancy Survey

title: Longest-Tenured in U.S.: CFOs
subhead: Paul Coghlan of Linear Technology is the longest-running CFO among the largest U.S. companies
overview: Bloomberg ranked CFOs on their tenure as of August 31, 2013, and identified 15 who have been in their jobs the longest.
methodology: Included at the top were 500 U.S. companies by market capitalization. Only CFOs still at their companies were considered. Murray Goldberg of Regeneron Pharmaceuticals is scheduled to retire on October 1, 2013.

title: Oldest Operating Reactors in the U.S.: Nuclear Power Plants
winner: Nine Mile Point Nuclear Station, Unit 1
subhead: One-fifth of all U.S. nuclear power plants have been operating for 40 years or more
overview: Bloomberg ranked U.S. nuclear power plants based on the start date of commercial operation.
methodology: Capacity factor refers to the ratio of available capacity (amount of electric power actually produced by a generating unit) to theoretical capacity (amount of electrical power that could have been produced if the unit had operatedcontinuously at full power). Capacity factors can exceed 100% for a variety of reasons. Fort Calhoun Station, which has a capacity factor of 0, is still licensed to operate so it is included on the list.

title: Most Vaccinated Children: States
subhead: Mississippi leads the U.S. in vaccinations for children; Alaska comes in last
overview: Bloomberg ranked the U.S. states and the District of Columbia based on the percentage of children ages 19 months to 35 months inoculated with seven vaccines recommended by the CDC.
methodology: Data are from July 2011 to June 2012 and are the latest available.
sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

title: Biggest Recoveries in Financial Sector: Stocks
subhead: These stocks rebounded after the financial crisis, though most have not come close to precrisis prices
overview: Bloomberg ranked U.S. financial companies on the percentage-point difference between their stock returns from October 9, 2007 to March 9, 2009, which were the high and low points of the S&P 500 prior to and during the financial-crisis period, and from March 9, 2009 to September 10, 2013, which was the recovery period.
methodology: Included were companies with market capitalizations of at least $10 billion on October 9, 2007 and available stock prices. Real estate companies and REITs were excluded. Prices reflect stock splits.

title: Highest-Paid in U.S. While Outearning Their CEOs: CFOs
subhead: Five of the 12 CFOs who most outearn their bosses work for tech companies
overview: Bloomberg ranked CFOs who outearned their companies' CEOs by the difference in total compensation between the two.
methodology: Includes CFOs of the top 500 U.S. companies by market capitalization. All compensation is for the 2012 fiscal year. Companies where the CFO or the CEO had been in his job for less than a year were excluded, as were CFOs who are no longer in their jobs. Carlyle Group has two co-chief executive officers; the compensation shown is the sum of their pay.

title: Biggest Prospective Bubbles: U.S. Cities
subhead: Unemployment and housing prices are rising in Yuma, indicating a bubble may be ahead
overview: Bloomberg ranked U.S. metropolitan areas based on the year-over-year increase in unemployment and median housing list prices.
methodology: Scores were calculated by averaging the two percentage ranks of both criteria. Only metropolitan areas with an increase in both unemployment and median housing list prices between July 2012 and July 2013 were included. Unemployment rates were not seasonally adjusted.
sources: U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics, Zillow

title: Worst On-Time Arrivals: Airlines
subhead: More than 40% of flights arrive late for two Chinese airlines
overview: Bloomberg ranked 16 international airlines by the percentage of on-time flight arrivals in 2013 through July 31.
methodology: Sample size is the number of flights for which FlightStats was able to capture arrival data. For most airlines sample size exceeded 90% of all flights. A flight is considered on time if it arrives at the gate within 15 minutes of the scheduled gate time. Cancellations were subtracted from the sample size before on-time percentages were calculated. Only airlines with a sample size of at least 100,000 flights were included.

title: Strongest in China: Banks
subhead: Bank of Beijing is the strongest bank in China, followed closely by Hang Seng Bank
overview: Bloomberg ranked Chinese banks based on five weighted ratios: Tier 1 capital, the ratio of a bankâ€™s core equity capital to its risk-weighted assets (accounting for 40% of the score); the ratio of nonperforming assets to total assets (20%); the ratio of reserves for loan losses to nonperforming assets (20%); the ratio of deposits to funding (15%); and the efficiency ratio, which compares costs with revenues (5%).
methodology: For two ratios--nonperforming assets to total assets and efficiency--a lower percentage is better; for the remaining ratios a higher percentage is preferred. Banks were ranked on each criterion and the ranks were added together to determine each bank's position in the list. Included were banks domiciled in China and Hong Kong with total assets of $100 billion or more as of August 31, 2013. Sixteen banks qualified; data were for their 2012 fiscal year.

title: Most Tech-CEO Alumni: Colleges
subhead: Princeton graduates lead in the number of tech CEOs
overview: Bloomberg ranked the colleges and universities of CEOs of 250 U.S. technology companies with market capitalizations of more than $1 billion.
methodology: The top 10 schools are displayed.

title: Most Tech-CEO Graduate School Alumni: Colleges
subhead: Harvard is the No. 1 graduate school for tech CEOs
overview: Bloomberg ranked the graduate schools of CEOs of 250 U.S. technology companies with market capitalizations of more than $1 billion
methodology: Rankings included all degrees received from those universities -- MBAs, J.D.s, Masters, etc. Schools at which the same CEO received multiple degrees are counted only once.

title: Most Female CFA Society Members: Global Regions
subhead: Almost one-quarter of CFA society members in the Asia-Pacific region are women
overview: Bloomberg ranked global regions based on the ratio of male to female members in local Chartered Financial Analyst (CFA) Institute chapters
methodology: Figures were aggregated.  Approximately 6% of members are in multiple CFA societies; about 90% of active members are CFA Charterholders. Active members include all those with a valid membership regardless of employment status.
sources: CFA Institute - Society Demographic Profile Report FY 2013

title: Fewest Female CFA Society Members: Countries
subhead: There are 11 male members for every female in Brazil and Japan's CFA societies
overview: Bloomberg ranked countries based on the ratio of male to female members in Chartered Financial Analyst (CFA) Institute chapters. Ranking excluded societies with fewer than 100 active members as of FY 2013.
methodology: Ranking excluded societies with fewer than 100 active members as of FY 2013. For countries with multiple CFA societies, figures were aggregated. Approximately 6% of members are in multiple CFA societies; about 90% of active members are CFA Charterholders. Active members include all those with a valid membership regardless of employment status. Argentina and Uruguay are represented by one local chapter.
sources: CFA Institute - Society Demographic Profile Report FY 2013

title: Most Female Members: U.S. CFA Societies
subhead: The District of Columbia's CFA society has the lowest male-to-female ratio of all CFA societies in the U.S.
overview: Bloomberg ranked local Chartered Financial Analyst (CFA) Institute chapters in the U.S. based on the ratio of male to female members.
methodology: Ranking excluded societies with fewer than 100 active members as of FY 2013. Approximately 6% of members are in multiple CFA societies; about 90% of active members are CFA Charterholders. Active members include all those with a valid membership regardless of employment status.
sources: CFA Institute - Society Demographic Profile Report FY 2013

title: Top Spenders on International Tourism: Countries
subhead: Chinese travelers spent a record $102 billion on international tourism last year
overview: Bloomberg ranked countries based on citizens' spending on international tourism in 2012.
methodology: To compare countries, total expenditures were shown in U.S. dollars, though the year-over-year increase was shown in local currencies. Data were collected by the World Tourism Organization (UNWTO) in June 2013.

title: World's Worst for Departures: Airports
subhead: Beijing and Shanghai's primary international airports had the worst departure delays in 2012
overview: Bloomberg ranked 35 international airports by flight departure delays in 2012.
methodology: Each airport received a departure-delay score based on the weighted sum of three degrees of lateness: late (15-29 minutes), very late (30-44 minutes) and excessively late (greater than 44 minutes). They were weighted 20%, 30% and 50%, respectively. Only completed flights for which FlightStats had final status were included. Cancellations were subtracted from the sample size before percentages were calculated. The sample size for most airports exceeded 90% of flights. Lateness was determined by scheduled versus actual gate time or, if that was unavailable, scheduled runway time versus actual runway time.

title: Worst On-Time Arrivals in U.S.: Airports
subhead: Newark Liberty has the worst on-time arrival record in the U.S., with SFO close behind
overview: Bloomberg ranked 29 major U.S. airports based on the percentage of flights that arrived on time in 2012.
methodology: Figures for 2011 were added for comparison. A flight is considered to be on time if it arrives at the gate within 15 minutes of scheduled arrival time.Â
sources: United States Department of Transportation, Bureau of Transportation Statistics

title: Best in Florida for Seniors: Counties
subhead: Sarasota County takes top honors in catering to the 65+ population
overview: Bloomberg ranked Florida counties with a critical mass of seniors to determine the best places for senior living.
methodology: Five equally weighted factors were considered: mobility, wealth, leisure, education and senior concentration. Ranking excluded counties with less than 20,000 or 15% of population ages 65 and older. Demographic data were extracted from the 2007-2011 5Y and 2009-2011 3Y American Community Surveys of the U.S. Census. The Institute for Health Metric & Evaluation (IHME) at the University of Washington provided the county-specific life expectancy for males and females. For the purpose of this study, 1985 to 2010 averages were used. Leisure establishment data were extracted from the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Food and drink places included full, limited-services and other restaurants and places that serve beverages. Entertainment places included arts, entertainment and recreation establishments. Retail places included retail and trade establishments. Travel-related places included scenic and sightseeing transportation by water, land and air; and travel agencies, tour operators and other related travel arrangement and reservation services. Counts for 2012 were preliminary and included only private establishments.
sources: U.S. Census, Bureau of Labor Statistics, Institute for Health Metric & Evaluation at the University of Washington

title: Top Tourist Destinations: Countries
subhead: International tourists are fondest of France though they spend more than twice as much in the U.S.
overview: Bloomberg ranked countries based on the number of international tourist arrivals in 2012 and identified the 15 with the most arrivals.
methodology: International tourists are overnight visitors who are nonresidents of that country. Arrivals to Germany and Italy were counted at collective tourism establishments, such as hotels, campsites and conference centers; arrivals to remaining countries were counted at frontiers. Tourist figures refer to number of arrivals, not number of persons. Data were collected as of June 2013.

title: Most Retirement Spent Alone for Women: States
subhead: Women in the U.S. live 16 years beyond retirement age and outlive men by 4.7 years on average
overview: Bloomberg ranked the 50 U.S. states and the District of Columbia based on the expected percentage of postretirement years females in each state will spend alone without a male life partner.
methodology: The percentage was calculated by dividing the average number of years a female was expected to outlive a male by the average postretirement life expectancy of the female. The ranking assumed a retirement age of 65. Data are latest available. Figures are rounded.
sources: 2013 Measure of America project of the Social Science Research Council, Institute for Health Metric & Evaluation (IHME) at the University of Washington

title: Highest Risk-Adjusted Returns in U.S. Tech: Companies
subhead: MasterCard has the best three-year risk-adjusted return among U.S. technology companies
overview: Bloomberg ranked the companies in the S&P 500 Information Technology Sector Index and the S&P 500 Internet & Catalog Retail Industry Index by their stocks' risk-adjusted returns from August 16, 2010 to August 16, 2013.
methodology: Excluded were TripAdvisor, which didn't have three years of history, and companies headquartered outside the U.S. Names of the CEOs of these companies and their most recent pay are also shown. (Pay is given as NA if CEO didn't serve for the full fiscal year.)  For Akamai Technologies, Analog Devices, Electronic Arts, FLIR Systems, Intel, Jabil Circuit, Symantec, Visa and Western Digital, the CEO listed is no longer the chief executive officer. Risk-adjusted returns for Cisco Systems, KLA-Tencor, Linear Technology, Microsoft, Oracle, Paychex and Western Digital were for the fiscal year ending in 2013, though the latest compensation data was for the 2012 fiscal year.

title: Biggest Change in Real Estate Loans: Countries
subhead: While residential real estate loans have cooled in the U.S., they're heating up in other countries
overview: Bloomberg ranked countries based on the change in the ratio of real estate loans to total loans.
methodology: Countries were ranked by the percentage-point difference in the fourth quarter of 2009 compared to the fourth quarter of 2012. Includes all countries with IMF data available for both quarters. Figures may not add up due to rounding.

title: Highest Growth in BRIC Fuel Consumption: Countries
subhead: While U.S. fuel consumption is declining, BRIC countries are picking up the pace
overview: Bloomberg ranked BRIC countries based on average annual growth in liquid fuel consumption from 2004 to 2014 (forecast).
methodology: Figures for each year represent millions of barrels consumed per day. Liquid fuel includes gasoline, jet fuel, fuel oil, butane and propane.

title: Most Cash in U.S.: Companies
subhead: Financial firms account for nine of the top 10 companies in the U.S. with the most cash
overview: Bloomberg ranked 1,222 U.S. companies for which data were available based on the latest quarterly cash and near-cash data.
methodology: The 25 companies with the most cash are displayed.

title: Most Cash in the World: Companies
subhead: Banks account for 20 of the top 25 on the list of global companies ranked by cash and near cash
overview: Bloomberg ranked 67,387 global companies based on cash and near cash as of the latest financial data available.
methodology: The 25 companies with the most cash are displayed.

title: Biggest Change in Employment: Countries
subhead: Singapore may have the biggest 10-year increase in employment in 2014; Portugal the largest decline
overview: Bloomberg ranked countries based on the percentage-point change between the 2004 employment-to-population ratio and the estimated ratio for 2014.
methodology: The ratio was calculated by dividing the number of people employed in each country by the population of that country. Only countries for which IMF data were available for 2004 and 2014 were included.
sources: International Monetary Fund World Economic Outlook Database

title: Highest GDP Growth: States
subhead: North Dakota's GDP growth since 2008 is almost three times that of second-place Texas
overview: Bloomberg ranked  the U.S. states and the District of Columbia by the change in real GDP from 2008 to 2012.
methodology: Data were the latest available.

title: Most Time Spent Daily: Activities
subhead: Americans work and watch television more, socialize and think less than they did in 2003
overview: Bloomberg ranked daily activities of full-time American workers based on the average amount of time spent on them in 2012.
methodology: Activities of more than 30 seconds were rounded to the nearest minute.

title: Best Graduation Rates: Colleges
subhead: Williams College is No. 1 among undergraduate schools with 93% of students graduating in four years
overview: Bloomberg ranked U.S. colleges and universities based on the four-year bachelor's-degree graduation rate at or above 80% for full-time first-time students.
methodology: Six-year and eight-year graduation rates were provided for comparison. Included were 1,941 public and private not-for-profit schools of four years or more that offer broad curricula; specialty schools were omitted such as military academies, seminaries and schools with religious focus, music and art schools, engineering schools, nursing schools and medical training schools.  Data were for 2010 to 2011, the most recently available school year.
sources: U.S. Department of Education, National Center for Education Statistics, Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System (IPEDS), 2010-2011 data, Student Graduation Rate component (final release)

title: Most Back-to-School Stores: States
subhead: New Jersey has more back-to-school shopping per square mile than any other state
overview: Bloomberg ranked the U.S. states based on the number of retail establishments that sell back-to-school merchandise per square land mile.
methodology: An establishment is a single physical location at which business is conducted. Retail totals were only for establishments identified in the following NAICS sectors and subsectors:  electronics and appliance stores; clothing and clothing accessory stores; sporting goods stores; hobby, toy and game stores; musical instrument and supplies stores; bookstores; general merchandise stores; and office supply and stationery stores. Data are for locations with paid employees only.  Land area data were rounded after calculating the stores per square mile.
sources: U.S. Census, County Business Patterns 2011 and Census 2010

title: Most Untaxed Overseas Profits in U.S. Technology: Companies
subhead: Microsoft accounts for 20% of the $416 billion U.S. tech companies hold in overseas profits
overview: Bloomberg ranked the 70 companies in the S&P 500 Information Technology Sector Index, along with the  five companies  in the S&P 500 Internet & Catalog Retail Index, based on the amount of undistributed earnings held outside the U.S.
methodology: The top 25 companies are displayed. Data were from the latest available Annual Report or Form 10-K filed by the company. Five companies (Fidelity National Information Services, Fiserv, Paychex, SAIC and Salesforce.com) did not have information available.

title: Most Profitable in Technology in U.S.: Companies
subhead: Apple is almost two times more profitable than its nearest rival
overview: Bloomberg ranked technology companies based on latest available annual net income. Included were the 70 companies in the S&P 500 Information Technology Index as well as the five companies in the Internet & Catalog Retail Industry Index.
methodology: Data were for fiscal year 2012 unless indicated.

title: Biggest Gap Between Male and Female Pay: CEOs
subhead: Women CEOs of S&P 500 companies earn 17% less than the average chief executive
overview: Bloomberg compared the total compensation received by female CEOs in the S&P 500 to the average received by CEOs of both genders in their respective industry groups and ranked the female CEOs by the percentage difference.
methodology: CEOs who were not in their jobs for the full fiscal year were excluded. Data were for companies' 2012 fiscal year, except for TJX Companies, whose 2013 fiscal year ended in January.

title: Biggest Gains, Single-Family Home Prices: U.S. Cities
subhead: Prices for single-family homes in Jacksonville, FL have increased more than 36% in one year
overview: Bloomberg ranked U.S. cities for which data were available based on the percentage increase in the median sale price of single-family homes in each city's metro area from June 2012 to June 2013.
methodology: Data were rounded.

title: Highest Dividend Yields in U.S.: Companies
subhead: A mortgage investor tops the list of companies with highest dividends relative to share price
overview: Bloomberg ranked U.S. companies based on dividend yield on July 24, 2013. The yield was based on the July 24, 2013 share price and on the last dividend or partnership distribution paid annualized.
methodology: The universe consisted of 1,000 companies with share prices of at least $1 and market capitalizations of at least $250 million. Equity and nonequity investment instruments (such as mutual funds and exchange-traded funds) were excluded as were companies with no share price on July 24 or a share price lower than it was one year earlier. Among the 180 companies that remained, the top 25 were identified. Hugoton Royalty Trust pays its dividend monthly; all other companies pay quarterly.

title: Dirtiest Beaches in the U.S.: States
subhead: A study shows that Ohio's beach water is the most contaminated in the U.S.
overview: Bloomberg ranked the U.S. states based on a study of the percentage of water samples taken from oceans and lakes that exceeded the recommended national health standards for designated beach areas in 2012.
methodology: Samples that exceed the standards indicate the potential presence of human or animal waste. Data were rounded.

title: Longest Life Span in the Americas: Countries
subhead: The U.S. is fourth after Canada, Costa Rica and Chile
overview: Bloomberg ranked countries in the Americas on life expectancy.
methodology: Life expectancy is defined as the number of years a newborn infant would live assuming that age-specific mortality levels are constant.

title: Most Married Residents: States
subhead: Only one-quarter of District of Columbia residents ages 15 and older are married
overview: Bloomberg ranked the U.S. states and the District of Columbia based on the percentage of the population ages 15 and older who are now married.
methodology: Ranking excludes people who are separated. Data were rounded.

title: Most Deficient Bridges: States
subhead: One-quarter of Pennsylvania's bridges are in need of repair
overview: Bloomberg ranked states and the District of Columbia based on the percentage of their bridges that are structurally deficient at last reporting in 2012.
methodology: A bridge is classified as "structurally deficient" if engineers have identified a major defect in its support structure or deck. Though not necessarily unsafe, these bridges require significant maintenance, rehabilitation or replacement. Highway bridges, those which are at least 20 feet long and with automobile traffic passing on the structure (not underneath it), were included. Traffic figures are daily averages of individual car trips based on annual totals.
sources: Transportation for America, Department of Transportation Federal Highway Administration

title: Longest Life Span in Western Europe: Countries
subhead: Even the shortest life expectancy in Western Europe is nearly 80 years
overview: Bloomberg ranked countries in Western Europe based on life expectancy.
methodology: Life expectancy is defined as the number of years a newborn infant is expected to live assuming that age-specific mortality levels are constant.

title: Longest Life Span in the OECD: Countries
subhead: The U.S. ranks in the lowest quartile of OECD countries for longevity
overview: Bloomberg ranked countries in the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development based on life expectancy.
methodology: Life expectancy is defined as the number of years a newborn infant is expected to live assuming that age-specific mortality levels are constant.

title: Widest Pay Gap Between CEOs and Salesclerks: States
subhead: Even the best-paid retail salesperson has to work 262 years to match the average retail CEO's annual pay
overview: Bloomberg ranked the U.S. states and the District of Columbia based on the number of years a retail salesperson working in each state would have to work to match one year of the average pay for a CEO in the retail discretionary industry sector.
methodology: CEO pay of $6.45 million for 2012 and $4 million for 2007 were calculated by averaging 2012 and 2007 fiscal-year total compensation of CEOs for more than 120 publicly traded U.S. retail discretionary companies.

title: Least Upwardly Mobile Low-Wage Workers: States
subhead: The American Dream is hardest to achieve in New Jersey for those stuck in low-paying jobs such as retail sales
overview: Bloomberg ranked the U.S. states and the District of Columbia based on the difficulty of obtaining upward mobility in a low-wage job, using retail salesperson pay as a proxy.
methodology: The Immobility Score is based on two socioeconomic factors that promote upward mobility: a college degree and housing. Each factor was scored 1 to100 with 100 being least mobile. The two scores were then averaged to create a single score. Ranking assumed one-quarter of pretax income goes toward receiving a college education. Tuition was based on academic years 2009-2013 and 2007-2010 public four-year in-state tuition and fees.
sources: Bureau of Labor Statistics, U.S. Census, The College Board

title: Highest Inflation: Countries
subhead: Inflation in Venezuela is more than 10 times greater than in the U.S.
overview: Bloomberg ranked 64 countries based on the percentage change in their Consumer Price Index from 2011 to 2012.
methodology: For Ukraine, the 2012 figure was estimated.

title: Hottest Days: States
subhead: Every state in the U.S. has had at least one 100-degree day in its history; 10 have hit 120 and hotter
overview: Bloomberg ranked the U.S. states based on the maximum temperature on record and validated by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, National Climate Data Center and/or the State Climate Extremes Committee.
methodology: The data may come from sources other than official NOAA-supervised weather stations, but are archived, officially recognized observations. Temperatures reflect most current information available (new values may take up to three months to appear as final data). For states whose maximum temperature occurred on multiple days, the latest date is shown.
sources: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, National Climatic Data Center

title: Most Unintentional Deaths: States
subhead: New Mexico and Montana are the most dangerous U.S. states; New Jersey is the safest
overview: Bloomberg ranked the U.S. states and the District of Columbia based on deaths by unintentional injury per 100,000 residents. Deaths caused by motor vehicles, poisoning, falls and choking (suffocation by ingestion or inhalation of food or other objects) were also included.
methodology: Data were the most recent available from the National Safety Council's analysis of National Center for Health Statistics Mortality Data for 2009.
sources: National Safety Council Injury Facts 2013 Edition

title: Longest Life Span in Asia Pacific: Countries
subhead: Hong Kong residents live 20 years more than those in East Timor, Papua New Guinea and Cambodia
overview: Bloomberg ranked countries in the Asia Pacific based on life expectancy.
methodology: Life expectancy is defined as the number of years a newborn infant is expected to live assuming that age-specific mortality levels are constant.

title: Highest-Paid at Companies That Lost Money: CEOs
subhead: Six CEOs whose companies showed negative net income and returns in 2012 were paid $10M or more
overview: Bloomberg ranked CEOs of the 746 U.S. companies that lost money and had negative total returns in their 2012 fiscal year based on total compensation, and identified the 15 CEOs with the highest pay.
methodology: All CEOs had to be in their jobs for the full year. Aubrey McClendon resigned his position at Chesapeake Energy on April 1, 2013.

title: Longest Life Span in Middle East and Africa: Countries
subhead: Israelis enjoy the longest life expectancy in their part of the world
overview: Bloomberg ranked Middle Eastern and African countries on life expectancy.
methodology: Life expectancy is defined as the number of years a newborn infant would live assuming that age-specific mortality levels are constant.

title: Most Oil-Dependent Economies: Countries
subhead: Libya and Singapore are counting on oil exports to grow their economies
overview: Bloomberg ranked countries based on change in oil exports as a percentage of GDP from 1993 to 2018.
methodology: The International Monetary Fund provided estimates for 2018. Included were countries with projected oil exports and GDP of at least $1 billion in 2018.
sources: International Monetary Fund's World Economic Outlook Database

title: Highest Ratio of Shale Gas to Natural Gas: Countries
subhead: In some countries the amount of shale gas available dwarfs natural gas reserves
overview: Bloomberg ranked countries based on the size of their accessible shale gas compared to the proved reserves of natural gas and identified the top 20.
methodology: The latest available data were used.

title: Biggest Increase in Beer Consumption: States
subhead: The Peace Garden State -- North Dakota -- increased beer consumption most from 2011 to 2012
overview: Bloomberg ranked the U.S. states and the District of Columbia based on change in consumption of beer from 2011 to 2012 .
methodology: Data were for per capita consumption of beer in 2012 and 2011 for residents ages 21 and older.
sources: Beer Institute; Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau; U.S. Census Bureau

title: Most Beer Consumption 2012: States
subhead: The Peace Garden State -- North Dakota -- ranks first in beer consumption
overview: Bloomberg ranked the U.S. states and the District of Columbia based on per capita consumption of beer in 2012 for residents ages 21 and older
methodology: Change in consumption was calculated for the five years from 2007-2012.
sources: Beer Institute; Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau; U.S. Census Bureau

title: Longest Life Span in E. Europe/Central Asia: Countries
subhead: The lifespan in Afghanistan is the shortest of Eastern Europe and Central Asia
overview: Bloomberg ranked countries in Eastern Europe and Central Asia based on life expectancy.
methodology: Life expectancy is defined as the number of years a newborn infant is expected to live assuming that age-specific mortality levels are constant.

title: Highest Unemployment: Countries
subhead: Four countries have jobless rates higher than 20%: Greece, Spain, South Africa and Nigeria
overview: Bloomberg ranked 70 countries and the euro zone based on the latest unemployment rates reported through June 28, 2013.
methodology: Figures for Kazakhstan and Vietnam are from the IMF.  Figures are rounded.

title: Most Financial Aid: Colleges
subhead: Boston University provides greatest amount of financial aid though only 55% of students who apply get it
overview: Bloomberg ranked the top 50 U.S. colleges and universities based on institutional grant aid they provided to full-time first-time undergraduates.
methodology: Included were 1,941 public and private not-for profit schools of four years or more. Schools were listed by campus if there was more than one campus. Total grant aid included institutional, federal and state/local grants. Data were for the most recently available school year.
sources: U.S. Department of Education, National Center for Education Statistics, Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System (IPEDS), 2010-2011 data, Student Financial Aid component (final release)

title: Biggest Prime Workforce: States
subhead: District of Columbia has the highest percentage of 25-to-44 year-old residents; Maine the lowest
overview: Bloomberg ranked the U.S. states and the District of Columbia by the percentage of 25-to-44 year-olds in their population, a proxy for the concentration of prime workforce.
methodology: Population data were as of 2011, the latest available.
sources: U.S. Census Bureau 2011 American Community Survey 1-Year Estimates

title: Highest Concentration of Restaurants: States
subhead: District of Columbia and Hawaii have the most restaurants per 1,000 households
overview: Bloomberg ranked the U.S. states and the District of Columbia based on restaurant concentration, defined as the number of eating and drinking establishments per 1,000 households.
methodology: Restaurant data and household data were as of 2011, the latest available.
sources: National Restaurant Association, U.S. Census Bureau

title: Highest Obesity Inequality/Females: Countries
subhead: Bangladesh has the largest ratio of underweight women to obese women in the world
overview: Bloomberg ranked countries based on the number of underweight women for every woman who is obese.
methodology: The 20 countries with the greatest disparity, calculated by dividing the percentage of underweight women by the percentage of obese women, are shown. Excluded were countries with fewer than 10 million female adults or those lacking sufficient data. Data were most recent available. Body Mass Index (BMI) is an index of weight-to-height used to classify underweight, overweight and obesity in adults. BMI classification: Underweight <18.5, Normal: 18.5 to 24.99, Overweight: 25 to 29.9, Obese: 30+.
sources: World Health Organization, United Nations Population Division

title: Highest Obesity Inequality/Males: Countries
subhead: Ethiopia has the largest ratio of underweight men to obese men in the world
overview: Bloomberg ranked countries based on the number of underweight men for every man who is obese.
methodology: The 20 countries with the greatest disparity, calculated by dividing the percentage of underweight men by the percentage of obese men, are shown. Excluded were countries with fewer than 10 million male adults or those lacking sufficient data. Data were most recent available. Body Mass Index (BMI) is an index of weight-to-height used to classify underweight, overweight and obesity in adults. BMI classification: Underweight <18.5, Normal: 18.5 to 24.99, Overweight: 25 to 29.9, Obese: 30+.
sources: World Health Organization, United Nations Population Division

title: Most Assets in U.S.: Banks
subhead: JPMorgan and Bank of America have combined total assets of nearly $4.6 trillion
overview: Bloomberg ranked 1,377 U.S. banks and institutional financial services companies by latest available total assets and identified the top 25.
methodology: All data were as of the first quarter of 2013. Security and commodity exchanges were excluded.

title: Least Expensive Housing Markets: U.S. Cities
subhead: Ocala, FL and Rockford, IL top the list for least expensive housing as of May 2013
overview: Bloomberg ranked U.S. cities for which data were available based on median home sale price in May 2013.
methodology: Data were for sales of all residential property types within the metro areas in which the cities are located.

title: Most Expensive Housing Markets: U.S. Cities
subhead: California has 12 of the 20 priciest housing markets
overview: Bloomberg ranked U.S. cities for which data were available based on median home sale price in May 2013.
methodology: Data were for sales of all residential property types within the metro areas in which the cities are located.

title: Most Foreclosures: U.S. Cities
subhead: Miami has the most foreclosures; the District of Columbia and New York City have the fewest
overview: Bloomberg ranked the 76 U.S. cities with at least 250,000 residents as of 2012 based on the number of homes in any stage of foreclosure as of May 2013.
methodology: Rates were per 1,000 homes. Data were rounded.

title: Greatest Growth in Car Sales Worldwide: Companies
subhead: Great Wall Motor posts a 42% five-year growth rate in car sales, nearly double its closest rival
overview: Bloomberg ranked the world's automakers by their growth from 2007 to 2012.
methodology: Growth was measured using compound annual growth rate. Only manufacturers of at least 500,000 vehicles with data for 2012 are shown. The 2007 data for Chrysler Group were before its reorganization and the 2007 General Motors data were prebankruptcy. Data for Renault-Nissan Group and Fiat-Chrysler were broken out by manufacturing unit due to missing data for 2012 and 2007, respectively.

title: Greatest Increase in Vehicle Sales: Countries
subhead: Emerging-markets countries are showing the greatest increase in vehicle sales
overview: Bloomberg ranked 37 countries with sales of 100,000 or more vehicles in 2007 and 2012 based on the change in sales during  that five-year period.
methodology: Ranks were determined by countries' compound annual growth rate. Vehicles in ranking include passenger cars, and may include light trucks, trucks, buses and other locally defined vehicles. World statistics are for passenger cars and light trucks.

title: Highest Youth Unemployment: Countries
subhead: In Greece and Spain, more than half of the labor force aged 15-25 is out of work
overview: Bloomberg ranked 32 countries, including the 28 countries of the European Union plus Japan, Norway, Turkey and the U.S. based on the unemployment rate for the population age 15-25.
methodology: Figures are the latest annual average for 2012, not seasonally adjusted, updated as of May 31, 2013. The rate doesn't include people studying full-time or those who are neither working nor looking for a job. They are not part of the labor force which is used as the denominator for calculating the unemployment rate.

title: Biggest Oil Producers: Countries
subhead: Russia and Saudi Arabia are neck-and-neck for top oil production, with the U.S. a distant third
overview: Bloomberg ranked countries based on their average daily oil production in 2012.
methodology: The 20 largest producers are displayed.

title: Top 20 by Profits Worldwide: Companies
subhead: Banks and integrated-oil companies dominate the list of 20 most profitable companies in the world
overview: Bloomberg ranked 67,260 publicly listed companies based on net income for their latest fiscal year. The top 20 are displayed.
methodology: Figures are for 2012 except for Wal-Mart which has reported 2013 results. BHP Billiton is a dually-listed company with BLT LN.

title: Biggest Increases in School Spending: States
subhead: D.C. increases spending on instruction most over 5 years while Alaska adds most to support services
overview: Bloomberg ranked the U.S. states and the District of Columbia based on the change in spending per pupil on instruction and support services for elementary and secondary schools from 2006 to 2011. Data were for school systems' fiscal years ending September 30, 2011, except for Alabama and D.C. where fiscal years ended in September; and Nebraska, Texas and Washington, which have August fiscal years. Enrollments used to calculate per-pupil amounts represented fall 2010 data collected by the National Center for Education Statistics.
methodology: Figures included salaries and wages and employment benefits. States were given a percentile rank on each factor and the two ranks were averaged to derive each state's spending score. The figures covered public school systems providing elementary and/or secondary programs for instruction from prekindergarten through 12th grade. Instructional spending was for teachers and others who assist in the instructional process. Support activities included guidance counseling, administration, transportation, plant operation, maintenance and food services.
sources: U.S. Census Bureau, Public Education Finances: 2011

title: Most Educated: States
subhead: DC residents hold almost double the number of advanced degrees of any state
overview: Bloomberg ranked the U.S. states and the District of Columbia based on their populations' levels of education.
methodology: States are ranked on the percentage of the population aged 25+ with bachelor's degrees or higher.
sources: U.S. Census Bureau  2011 American Community Survey 1-Year Estimates

title: Greatest Decrease in Marriages: States
subhead: Tennessee has seen the most precipitous drop in marriages over the last decade
overview: Bloomberg ranked U.S. states and the District of Columbia on the change in marriage rate from 2001 to 2011.
methodology: Included were the marriages per 1,000 residents from 2002 to 2011. Data were not available for Oklahoma prior to 2004 and for Louisiana in 2006. Nevada and Hawaii were excluded due to unusually high marriage rates, presumably because of their popularity for "destination" weddings.
sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

title: Highest Pay for a High School Diploma: Jobs
subhead: Managers lacking a college diploma still make six figures
overview: Bloomberg ranked the median annual pay of occupations held by individuals with a high school diploma. The 20 highest-paying jobs were listed.
methodology: Excluded were occupations with fewer than 10,000 jobs nationwide or lacking sufficient data. Pay includes base rate, cost-of-living allowances, guaranteed pay, hazardous-duty pay and incentive pay, including commissions, production bonuses and tips.  Data were released in April 2013 for the year 2012.
sources: U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics, Education-Portal.com

title: Highest Pay for a Bachelor's Degree: Jobs
subhead: Chief executives make the most among professional in jobs that don't require advanced degrees
overview: Bloomberg ranked the median annual pay for jobs held by individuals with bachelor's degrees. The 20 highest-paying jobs were listed.
methodology: Excluded were occupations with fewer than10,000 jobs nationwide or lacking sufficient data. Pay includes base rate, cost-of-living allowances, guaranteed pay, hazardous-duty pay and incentive pay, including commissions, production bonuses and tips. Data were released in April 2013 for the year 2012.
sources: U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics, Education-Portal.com

title: Highest Pay for an Advanced College Degree: Jobs
subhead: Anesthesiologists top the chart for highest earnings in professions requiring advanced degrees
overview: Bloomberg ranked the median annual pay of occupations held by individuals with advanced degrees. The 20 highest-paying jobs at each educational level were listed.
methodology: Excluded were occupations with fewer than10,000 jobs nationwide or lacking sufficient data. Pay includes base rate, cost-of-living allowances, guaranteed pay, hazardous-duty pay and incentive pay, including commissions, production bonuses and tips. For the five best-paid jobs in the advanced degree category, median pay figures were not available and mean annual pay figures were used. Data were released in April 2013 for the year 2012.
sources: U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics, Education-Portal.com

title: Highest Pay for Some College: Jobs
subhead: Air traffic controllers can earn six figures even without a four-year degree
overview: Bloomberg ranked the median annual pay of occupations held by individuals with some college experience. The 20 highest-paying jobs were listed.
methodology: Excluded were occupations with fewer than 10,000 jobs nationwide or lacking sufficient data. Pay includes base rate, cost-of-living allowances, guaranteed pay, hazardous-duty pay and incentive pay, including commissions, production bonuses and tips. "Some college" includes occupations with the following minimum educational requirements: associate's degree, some college but no degree and/or postsecondary nondegree programs.  Data were released in April 2013 for the year 2012.
sources: U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics, Education-Portal.com

title: Highest Pay without a High School Diploma: Jobs
subhead: No high school diploma? You can still make a decent living as a mine shuttle car operator
overview: Bloomberg ranked the median annual pay of occupations held by individuals without a high school diploma. The 20 highest-paying jobs were listed.
methodology: Excluded were occupations with fewer than10,000 jobs nationwide or lacking sufficient data. Pay includes base rate, cost-of-living allowances, guaranteed pay, hazardous-duty pay and incentive pay, including commissions, production bonuses and tips. Data were released in April 2013 for the year 2012.
sources: U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics, Education-Portal.com

title: Most Consumers with Student Loan Debt: States
subhead: DC and Minnesota have the highest percentage of consumers with student loan debt
overview: Bloomberg ranked the U.S. states and the District of Columbia based on the percentage of consumers who have student loan debt.
methodology: Consumers are defined as people with a credit record. Figures include borrowers not currently in repayment, who account for 44 percent of all borrowers. Delinquency rates for loans in the repayment cycle are roughly twice as high as those above, according to the New York Federal Reserve. All data are as of year end 2012.
sources: Federal Reserve Bank of New York Consumer Credit Panel / Equifax

title: Highest Concentration of Arts Majors: States
subhead: New York has highest concentration of visual/performing arts majors, the lowest-paying college major
overview: Bloomberg ranked the U.S. states and the District of Columbia based on the percentage of the population ages 25 and older with a visual and performing arts degree.
methodology: Percentages were calculated by identifying residents over the age of 25 who received Bachelor's degrees in visual and performing arts.

title: Highest Concentration of Engineering Majors: States
subhead: Michigan has the highest percentage of people who studied engineering, the best-paying college major
overview: Bloomberg ranked the U.S. states and the District of Columbia based on the percentage of the population age 25 and older who have engineering degrees.
methodology: Percentages were calculated by identifying residents over the age of 25 who received Bachelor's degrees in engineering.

title: Getting Fatter Fastest: States
subhead: Delaware residents have shown the greatest increase in adult obesity
overview: Bloomberg ranked the U.S. states and the District of Columbia based on the growth in numbers of obese adults from 2000 to 2011.
methodology: Figures on obesity were obtained from telephone interviews conducted by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention; 2011 data included mobile phone users while previous years included only landline telephone users.
sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, U.S. Census Bureau

title: Lowest Ratio of Obesity to Health Coaches: States
subhead: In general, states with lower levels of obesity have the most help maintaining a healthy lifestyle
overview: Bloomberg ranked the U.S. states and the District of Columbia on the gap between the concentration of obese adults and the concentration of "health coaches": lifestyle-promoting professionals including dietitians, nutritionists, fitness trainers and aerobics instructors.
methodology: The Health gap is the (adjusted) percentage-point difference between the concentration of obese adults and health coaches. Numbers for the latter professions were extracted from the Bureau of Labor Statistics Occupational Employment Statistics and aggregated. Self-employed workers were excluded from the OES survey. Data are most recently available.
sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics

title: Highest Rents: U.S. Cities
subhead: Five of the top 10 most expensive places to rent a home are in California
overview: Bloomberg ranked the 50 most populous U.S. metropolitan statistical areas as of 2009 on median gross rents for 2011, the latest year available.
methodology: Figures were released by the U.S. Census in April 2013. "Gross rent" is the monthly rent plus the estimated average monthly cost of utilities (electricity, gas, water, sewer) and fuel (oil, coal, kerosene, wood, etc.). The U.S. Census considers households "burdened" if their gross rent amounts to more than 35% of household income. The top 20 MSAs are displayed.
sources: U.S. Census Bureau, American Community Survey

title: Top 20 by Revenue Worldwide: Companies
subhead: Integrated-oil companies account for seven of the world's top 10 ranked by revenue
overview: Bloomberg ranked 67,260 publicly listed companies based on revenue for their latest fiscal year. The top 20 are displayed.
methodology: For all companies on this list except Wal-Mart Stores, which reported 2013 results, figures are for 2012. Revenues shown for Glencore Xtrada are for Glencore International.

title: Top 20 by Revenue in U.S.: Companies
subhead: Revenue for top-ranked Wal-Mart is more than double that of third-place Chevron
overview: Bloomberg ranked 3,778 publicly traded U.S.-domiciled companies based on revenue for their latest fiscal year.
methodology: Data for all companies listed except for Wal-Mart and McKesson, which reported 2013 results, are for 2012.

title: Top 20 by Profits in U.S.: Companies
subhead: Apple is more profitable than Microsoft and IBM combined, Exxon Mobil is #1
overview: Bloomberg ranked 3,778 publicly listed U.S.-domiciled companies based on net income for their latest fiscal year.
methodology: Data for all companies listed except for Wal-Mart, which reported 2013 results, are for 2012.

title: Top-Selling Contemporary: Female Artists
subhead: Sale prices of Yayoi Kusama's works are up an average of 880% since 2002
overview: Bloomberg ranked living women artists based on sales of works at auction from 1985 through May 31, 2013.
methodology: Sales included buyers' premiums. Dual nationality artists, or those born in one country who spent most of their working life in another, are noted.

title: Most Smoker-Friendly: States
subhead: Smokers have the most freedom in Kentucky, West Virginia and Mississippi
overview: Bloomberg ranked the U.S. states and the District of Columbia based on their acceptance of smoking.
methodology: Three factors were considered: combined percentage of adults who smoke cigarettes either "every day" or "some days"; excise tax imposed on each pack of cigarettes; and legislation restricting smoking in bars, restaurants and private worksites. Each factor was scored from 0 to 100, with 100 signifying most tolerance for smokers. The final "smoker-friendly" score is an average of the three scores. For the first two categories, the state with the lowest smoker-friendly value was given a score of 0, while the state with the highest value was given a score of 100. All other states were given scores depending on where their values fell between these two extremes, based on a percentile basis. For legislation, each location was given a score of 0 for "Banned," 33.33 for "Separate Ventilated Areas," 66.67 for "Designated Areas" and 100 for "None/No Provision." These three scores were averaged into a final legislation score. "No Provision" indicates there is no provision in the law that requires any restriction on smoking, while "None" means there is a provision stating that smoking is permitted. "Designated Areas" do not have to be separately enclosed while "Separate Ventilated Areas" must be enclosed rooms with independent ventilation that does not allow smoke to infiltrate other indoor areas. Smoking rates are from 2011 while tax rates and legislation are from 2013. All figures are latest available. Tax figures are rounded.
sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

title: Most Overpaid in Banking Industry: CEOs
subhead: Richard Fairbank and Lloyd Blankfein were paid too much in 2012 based on their performance
overview: Bloomberg ranked the 20 biggest North American banks by assets on whether their CEOs were overcompensated or undercompensated.
methodology: First, the banks were ranked on three different measures to assess their results and size as of the end of each company's 2012 fiscal year: stock performance, return on common equity, and total assets, including cash and investments. Then the average of the share performance, ROE and asset scores for each bank were calculated to establish an average rank for them. Each CEO's compensation standing was subtracted from his or her bank's average rank. (Total compensation includes salaries, stock awards, bonuses and long-term incentive awards given to CEOs for their performance in 2012, which is not always the same as the figures that appear in proxies' Summary Compensation Tables.) The CEOs with the biggest difference between the two rankings were regarded as the most overcompensated.

title: Most Miserable: States
subhead: Louisiana is No. 1 in this second annual ranking of most miserable states in the U.S.
overview: Bloomberg ranked U.S. states based on their levels of misery-inducing factors.
methodology: Thirteen variables from the United Health Foundation's America's Health Rankings were isolated to determine each state's Misery Score. For each variable, the state with the maximum misery value received 100 points, while the state with the minimum value received zero points. All other states received points in proportion to where their values fell between the two extremes. Each state's 13 scores were then averaged for a final Misery Score. A higher score indicates greater misery. Air pollution levels refer to micrograms of fine particles per cubic meter. High school graduation rates refer to percent of incoming ninth graders who graduate within four years. Poor health days refer to the number of days in which a person could not perform work or household tasks due to poor mental or physical health. Premature death refers to loss of years of productive life due to death before age 75. Personal income refers to income from all sources and is not inflation adjusted. For income distribution, a higher Gini ratio indicates greater income inequality. Unemployment plus underemployment refers to total unemployed, plus all marginally attached workers, plus total employed part-time for economic reasons, as a percent of the civilian labor force plus all marginally attached workers. Employment data are the averages of figures from 2Q 2012 through 1Q 2013. All other data are from 2012.
sources: America's Health Rankings--United Health Foundation, U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics, U.S. Bureau of Economic Analysis

title: Fastest-Growing Moving Destinations: U.S. Cities
subhead: San Francisco is the fastest-growing moving destination over the last two years
overview: Bloomberg ranked cities based on the average percentage growth of inbound moves in 2011 and  2012. Move-in growth shows the percentage by which moves into the city exceeded moves out of the city.
methodology: Average growth is the geometric mean of the 2011 and 2012 growth percentages. Only cities among the top 30 cities for growth in both years were included.

title: Top-Grossing in U.S.: Movies
subhead: Adjusted for ticket-price inflation, Gone with the Wind was the highest grossing film in U.S. history.
overview: Bloomberg ranked the 20 domestic top-grossing U.S. films by U.S. box-office receipts adjusted for ticket-price inflation.
methodology: Adjusted gross receipts for all releases were calculated by multiplying estimated admissions of each film by the 2013 average ticket price of $7.94.

title: Most Paid Time Off: Countries
subhead: Austrian and Portuguese workers get 35 paid days off each year, while U.S. workers are guaranteed nothing
overview: Bloomberg ranked select countries based on the number of paid days off entitled to workers by federal law.
methodology: Ranking includes paid vacation days and paid holidays. Certain countries' laws refer to total time off in calendar days or weeks; for these cases, the number of equivalent work days was used, assuming a five-day work week. Ranking does not include paid leave for other reasons, such as illness or parental leave.
sources: Center for Economic and Policy Research

title: Fastest Aging Within One Generation: Countries
subhead: South Korea's concentration of 65+ residents has almost tripled within one generation
overview: Bloomberg ranked the 25 countries with the highest "aging multiple," growth of their senior population during approximately one generation (1981 to 2011).
methodology: Excluded were countries with fewer than 3 million residents ages 65+ in 2011.

title: Favorite Locations of High-Tech Companies: Countries
subhead: More than 20% of publicly listed companies in the U.S. are in the high-tech field
overview: Bloomberg ranked countries based on their percentage of publicly listed high-tech companies.
methodology: The following industries were included:  aerospace and defense, biotechnology, hardware, software, semiconductors, Internet software and services and renewable energy. Excluded were companies with market capitalizations of less than $1 million and countries with fewer than 100 public companies.

title: Biggest Increases In Lobbying in U.S.: Companies
subhead: Google tops other large companies on growth in lobbying spending, while Apple spends less
overview: Bloomberg ranked the 30 largest U.S. companies by market cap based on their percentage increase in lobbying spending from 2011 to 2012.
methodology: Lobbying data for 1Q 2013 were collected on April 29, 2013.  Data were rounded.

title: Least Earnings Potential: Jobs
subhead: Mail carriers, shampooers, and fast-food cooks have the lowest upside earnings potential
overview: Bloomberg ranked occupations based on upside earnings potential by calculating the ratio of pay for the top 10% of workers to pay for the bottom 10% of workers.
methodology: Excluded were managerial positions, jobs that pay at least $100,000 at 10th percentile, occupations with fewer than 10,000 jobs nationwide and occupations without sufficient data. Study was based on BLS OES 2012 by state data. Pay included base rate, cost-of-living allowances, guaranteed pay, hazardous-duty pay, incentive pay, including commissions and production bonuses and tips. Earnings were state averages.

title: Most Earnings Potential: Jobs
winner: Securities, Commodities and Financial Services Sales Agents
subhead: Traders, athletes and real estate brokers have the highest earnings potential
overview: Bloomberg ranked occupations based on upside earnings potential by calculating the ratio of pay for the top 10% of workers to pay for the bottom 10% of workers.
methodology: Excluded were managerial positions, jobs that pay at least $100,000 at the10th percentile, occupations with fewer than 10,000 jobs nationwide and occupations without sufficient data. Study was based on BLS OES 2012 by state data. Pay included base rate, cost-of-living allowances, guaranteed pay, hazardous-duty pay, incentive pay, including commissions and production bonuses and tips. Earnings were state averages

title: Most Innovative in the U.S.: Companies
subhead: Cyberonics, a Houston-based medical device maker, is the most innovative company in the U.S.
overview: Bloomberg ranked S&P 1500 companies using an innovation index score, which has a highest value of 100.
methodology: The innovation index used three factors: EBITDA margin, R&D expenditure to sales and enterprise value per share. Companies were ranked for 2012 and on growth the last three years in each factor. Annual growth rates were determined using the least-squares growth rate. Companies lacking data needed to calculate growth rates were excluded, as were companies that had negative growth. Industries were determined using the BICS level 3 and level 4 classifications.

title: Biggest Involving Internet Companies: Takeover Deals
subhead: Tumblr acquisition is 3rd largest public-company takeover of a private Internet company in a decade
overview: Bloomberg ranked public company acquisitions of private companies in the Internet industry based on deal value in the last 10 years.
methodology: Ranking included pending or completed takeovers of private companies by a single public company, with either or both parties in the Internet industry. Only deals of at least $100 million and with announced or amendment dates from May 20, 2003, through May 20, 2013, were considered. Facebook's acquisition of Instagram was included because the deal was completed after Facebook went public.
