title: Strongest in the U.S.: Banks
subhead: Citigroup is the strongest bank in the U.S.
overview: Bloomberg ranked U.S. banks with total assets of $50 billion or more as of mid-May based on five factors.
methodology: This ranking was created by multiplying each bank's rank in each of five factors by the factor's weight to derive a score. The five scores were added together to determine the bank's final rank. Tier 1 capital ratio, the ratio of a bank's core equity capital to its risk-weighted assets, received a weighting of 40 percent. The ratio of nonperforming assets to total assets received a weighting of 20 percent, as did the ratio of reserves for loan losses to nonperforming assets. The ratio of deposits to funding accounted for 15 percent of the final score, and the efficiency ratio, which compares costs with revenues, received a 5 percent weighting. Banks that reported a loss for their 2012 net income or whose capital plan was rejected by the Federal Reserve were excluded. All data were for banks' 2012 fiscal year, which in most cases ended December 31. Banks that hadn't reported 2012 year-end data by May 20 were not included. Only banks with at least $50 billion in assets were considered, and only the top 10 are displayed.

title: Biggest Pay Premiums for Dual-Role CEOs: Industries
subhead: CEOs who are also Chairmen earn 16% more than CEOs who are not
overview: Bloomberg ranked industries based on the pay premium of S&P 500 CEOs who are both CEO and Chairman versus those who are not.
methodology: Bloomberg recorded the total pay of CEOs from the summary compensation table of their proxy statements, and calculated the difference between CEOs who are also chairman and those who have a single role.

title: Most Stressed-Out: Countries
subhead: A stress test shows life is toughest in Nigeria, easiest in Norway
overview: Bloomberg ranked countries based on the stressfulness of their living environments.
methodology: Seven equally weighted variables were considered: homicide rates, GDP per capita on a purchasing-power-parity basis, income inequality, corruption perception, unemployment, urban air pollution and life expectancy. Income inequality was measured by the Gini Index, where a score of 0 represents perfect equality and 100 perfect inequality. Corruption perception refers to Transparency International's Corruption Perceptions Index, which scores countries on a scale of 0 to 100, with 0 being the most corrupt. Urban outdoor air pollution is the annual mean concentration of fine particles smaller than 10 microns, measured in micrograms per cubic meter. Countries were allotted points for each variable based on their relative position in that category's ranking. The country with the least-stressful measure for each variable received 0 points, while the country with the highest stress level received 100 points. All other countries were scored on a percentile basis depending on their position between the two extremes. Points for the seven variables were averaged for a final score from 0 to 100, a higher score indicating a more stressful living environment. All data were the latest available. Only countries with data available for all seven variables were included.
sources: United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime, International Monetary Fund, Central Intelligence Agency World Factbook, Transparency International, World Health Organization

title: Most Decadent: Countries
subhead: Czech Republic is the world's most decadent country
overview: Bloomberg ranked countries on their propensity for vice, measured by alcohol and cigarette consumption, drug use and gambling levels.
methodology:
The four variables--total adult per capita alcohol consumption, total adult per capita cigarette consumption, annual prevalence of drug use as a percentage of the population ages 15-64, and total gambling losses as a percentage of GDP--were weighted equally. For alcohol and cigarettes, "adult" includes all residents ages 15 and older. Drug-use figures cover five equally weighted categories: amphetamines, cannabis, cocaine, ecstasy and opioids (including prescription opioids). 
The country with the maximum value in each variable received 25 points for that variable; the country with the minimum value received zero points. All other countries were scored  based on their percentile positions within the maximum-minimum band. Points for each variable were summed for a final score, with a range of 0-100. A higher score indicates a higher propensity for vice. All data are the latest available. Only countries with data for all categories were included.
sources: World Health Organization, Tobacco Atlas, United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime, Global Betting and Gaming Consultants

title: Highest Salaries in OECD: Countries
subhead: The U.S. leads OECD countries in salaries while Spain, Italy, Israel are in bottom half
overview: Bloomberg ranked OECD countries on average annual wages.
methodology: Data were from 2011 and reflected salaries of full-time employees and full-year equivalent employees (employees on part-time schedules converted to a full-time basis). Salaries were adjusted for purchasing power parity, which allows for the comparison of costs in one country with another.
sources: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development

title: Lowest-Paying, Most Dangerous: Jobs
subhead: Fishermen and loggers have the most dangerous jobs--and aren't rewarded for it
overview: Bloomberg ranked U.S. occupations based on the ratio of wages to on-the-job fatalities.
methodology: Only occupations from the BLS's Injuries, Illnesses, and Fatalities database that had corresponding wage data from the BLS's Occupational Employment Statistics database were considered. The final list of 42 jobs excluded occupations deemed too broad or that overlapped with other occupations. The Dead-end-job score was calculated by dividing a job's annual wages by its fatality rate, and dividing the result by 100. A lower score indicates a lower ratio of wages to on-the-job deaths. A higher score indicates that workers are better compensated for the risk. Workers under the age of 16, volunteers and military occupations were excluded. Fatality rates were from 2011 and included BLS's revised figures released April 25, 2013. Wage data were from May 2012.

title: Worst for Minimum-Wage Workers: States
subhead: D.C., New Jersey, New York are worst places to be a minimum-wage worker
overview: Bloomberg ranked the U.S. states on hourly minimum wage as a percentage of per capita hourly income.
methodology: According to the BEA, "Personal income is the income received by all persons from all sources. It is the sum of net earnings by place of residence, property income, and personal current transfer receipts." Hourly personal income was calculated by dividing the annual personal income rate by 2000 (40 hours per week for 50 weeks). Minimum-wage rates were as of February 13, 2013. Some states' minimum wages exceed the federal minimum wage of $7.25 per hour. For states with statutory minimum wages of less than $7.25 or with no minimum wage, the federal rate supersedes the state rate. BEA state personal income rates were from Q2 2012 and Census state population estimates were for July 1, 2012. In Missouri, federally covered employment and employees of a retail or service business with gross annual sales or business of less than $500,000 are exempt from state minimum wage. In Nevada, minimum wage is for workers with no health insurance benefits provided by employer; the rate is $7.25 for workers with health insurance provided by employer. In Ohio, minimum wage is $7.25 for employers grossing $283,000 or less.
sources: National Conference of State Legislatures, U.S. Department of Labor, U.S. Census Bureau, U.S. Bureau of Economic Analysis

title: Best for Workers: Countries
subhead: Looking for good pay, generous benefits and smart colleagues? Head to Ireland or France
overview: Bloomberg ranked OECD countries based on their working environment.
methodology: The ranking focused on compensation and quality of peers, assuming that workers would prefer countries where they can expect to be competitively compensated, have the least amount of direct outlay for their own health care and retirement, and have productive and educated colleagues. Competitiveness of pay was divided into three factors: annual wages, calculated by annualizing monthly wage data in local currency from the International Labor Organization and converting figures into U.S. dollars using year-end exchange rates for each of the five years; compensation, such as cash and in-kind payments, as well as contributions to social security and pension, as a percentage of expense; and out-of-pocket spending on health care, such as direct outlay to health practitioners, pharmaceuticals and therapeutic devices. Quality of peers included: productivity (GDP per person employed); labor force participation; and labor force with tertiary education. For each factor, countries were scored as percentages to the maximum value within the OECD. Factors were then averaged to derive the total score for each country. Countries with fewer than five data points were excluded. The most recent five-year average data available were used to smooth out the short-term volatility due to recent financial swings.
sources: OECD, International Labor Organization, IMF, The Conference Board, World Bank

title: Lowest-Paid Boards: Companies
subhead: Berkshire Hathaway board members earned $34,000 in 2012, less than any large U.S. company
overview: Bloomberg ranked the boards of the 500 largest market-cap companies in the U.S. on total compensation.
methodology: Figures were the latest available as of April 30, 2013. Included companies with stock trading history and total-return data for at least two years, from 12/31/10 to 12/31/12.

title: The EU's Busiest Psychiatrists: Countries
subhead: Psychiatrists in Portugal have the EU's most crowded couches
overview: Bloomberg ranked EU countries based on the annual number of patients per psychiatrist.
methodology: To calculate the patients-per-psychiatrist ratio, the number of citizens who had consulted a psychiatrist in the previous 12 months (February 2009 to February 2010) was divided by the number of psychiatrists in each country (according to OECD database and WHO reports, using latest year available). Figures for Italy and Bulgaria were not available.
sources: OECD, European Commission, World Health Organization

title: Most Worried About by Aging Rich People: Concerns
subhead: Young rich people fear losing memory and gaining weight as they age
overview: Bloomberg ranked aging concerns of rich people by age group and by gender, and highlighted the 15 biggest worries of people ages 30-44.
methodology: Data came from a Luxury Institute poll of 589 consumers in the U.S. with a minimum gross annual income of at least $150,000. The survey, completed in the first quarter of 2012, concentrated on aging concerns and the use of anti-aging regimens.

title: Most Underachieving: CEOs
subhead: HP's performance during her tenure puts Whitman first among S&P 100 underachievers
overview: Bloomberg ranked CEOs who were in their jobs for at least one year as of April 30 on their company's stock performance compared to the S&P 500 during their tenure.
methodology: Companies were drawn from the S&P 100 as of April 30, 2013. Annualized total return for each CEO was calculated from the day the CEO started until April 30.

title: Highest Showbiz Pay: States
subhead: Actors earn the most in Hawaii, while California is most lucrative for film and video editors
overview: Bloomberg ranked the U.S. states and the District of Columbia on 2002-2012 average composite pay for four representative show-business occupations.
methodology: State-by-state and year-by-year detailed data for the four occupations (actor, audio and video equipment technician, camera operator and film/video editor) were extracted from annual releases put out by the Bureau of Labor Statistics' Occupational Employment Statistics.  To come up with composite pay for each state, the ten-year average hourly wage for every occupation was calculated and averaged for the four occupations each year.
sources: Bureau of Labor Statistics' Occupational Employment Statistics

title: Most Showbiz Jobs: States
subhead: New Mexico has the highest concentration of actors
overview: Bloomberg ranked the U.S. states and the District of Columbia on the 2002-2012 average composite job concentration of four representative show-business occupations.
methodology: Job concentration levels were calculated by summing the number of showbiz jobs (actor, audio and video equipment technician, camera operator and film/video editor) per 10,000 jobs in each state.
sources: Bureau of Labor Statistics' Occupational Employment Statistics

title: Wealthiest Retired Residents: U.S. Cities
subhead: Crows Nest, Indiana, is home to some of the wealthiest retirees in the U.S.
overview: Bloomberg ranked U.S. cities on average annual household retirement income
methodology: Places with less than $75,000 in average household retirement income, median home values less than $500,000 and fewer than 100 residents were excluded. Retirement incomes include retirement pensions, survivor benefits or disability income from an employer, labor union, federal, state, or local government or the U.S. military; periodic receipts from annuities and insurance; and regular income from IRA and Keogh plans. Retirement income does not include Social Security.

title: Longest Commutes: U.S. Cities
subhead: Almost one-third of New York City workers travel at least an hour to get to their jobs
overview: Bloomberg ranked U.S. cities with available data on travel time from home to work.
methodology: U.S. cities with at least 250,000 workers who do not work at home were ranked on two factors: the percentage of workers 16 years of age and older whose commute from home to work was greater than 60 minutes; and the average commuting time. They were given a corresponding point score from 0 to 100 on each factor. The ranks were summed and divided by the highest possible total to determine the final commuting score.

title: Highest-Paid While Outearning Their CEOs: Executives
subhead: Blackstone COO Tony James was paid nearly four times more than CEO Schwarzman in 2012
overview: Bloomberg ranked named executive officers whose total compensation for the latest fiscal year exceeded that of their CEO.
methodology:
Included were the top 500 U.S. companies by market capitalization that, as of April 17, had filed a proxy for their latest fiscal year. Data were taken from proxies' Summary Compensation Tables. For companies with more than one CEO, executives were compared to the CEO who received the highest pay.
Notes: COO is chief operating officer. Apple's Mansfield announced in May 2012 that he would be retiring. His compensation for 2012 reflects the fair value of a modified vesting schedule for the restricted stock he was granted in November 2011. Patrick Gelsinger is CEO of VMware, whose parent company is EMC. Walter Robb is Co-CEO of Whole Foods Market with John Mackey, and William Conway is Co-CEO of the Carlyle Group with David Rubenstein. John Frank is Principal Executive Officer at Oaktree Capital Group.

title: Most Tax Revenue from Alcohol, Tobacco, Betting: States
subhead: Texas receives more tax money from "sin" than any other state
overview: Bloomberg ranked states based on the 2012 U.S. Census survey of State Government Tax Collections from sales and gross receipts for alcohol, tobacco and pari-mutuels.
methodology: Pari-mutuels include tax revenue measured by amounts wagered or bet on such activities as horseracing, dog racing and Jai-alai and excludes taxes on racetrack admissions and licenses. Statistics were for state government fiscal years ending on June 30, 2012 except for Alabama and Michigan (September 30), New York (March 31) and Texas (August 31). West Virginia's figure for alcohol was an estimate for taxes collected on sales of alcoholic beverages by private businesses, calculated by subtracting taxes from state-run liquor sales from total taxes collected from liquor sales, according to the census.

title: Most Profitable Employees: Companies
subhead: InterDigital, Rosetta Resources top list of companies with highest net income per employee
overview: Bloomberg ranked companies in the S&P 1500 based on net income per employee.
methodology: To determine net income per employee, each company's latest available net income was divided by its number of employees for the same period. Included companies with 2012 or 2013 fiscal-year data available. Excluded real estate investment trusts and companies with fewer than 100 employees.

title: U.S. Brain Gains: Countries
subhead: The most highly skilled immigrants in the U.S. come from India
overview: Bloomberg ranked countries on their average loss of specialty-occupation workers to the U.S. from 2009 to 2011.
methodology: Figures for H-1B specialty-occupation worker petitions were extracted from the "Characteristics of H-1B Specialty Occupation Workers," an annual report prepared by Homeland Security and U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services. The top 20 counts by country of birth of beneficiary were recorded for the three fiscal years and an average was calculated to determine each country's share of total H-1B petitions approved and the brain drain they represented for their home country. The general duration of an H-1B visa is three years and can be extended for another three years. Numbers for Israel were based on the 2009 and 2010 reports, Spain appeared in just 2010 and 2011, and Argentina was only in the 2009 report. The U.S. requires that "the nature of the specific duties be so specialized and complex that the knowledge required to perform the duties is usually associated with the attainment of a bachelor's or higher degree" for a visa for specialty occupations.
sources: Homeland Security, International Labor Organization, CIA World Factbook

title: Highest Pay for Tech Jobs: States
subhead: Jobs in science, technology, engineering and math pay about 64% more than the average occupation
overview: Bloomberg ranked U.S. states and the District of Columbia based on pay for jobs related to science, technology, engineering and mathematics.
methodology: Pay for STEM (science, technology, engineering and math) jobs was calculated as the employment number-weighted average annual wage of the following three occupational groups from the Bureau of Labor Statistics Occupational Employment Statistics (BLS OES): Computer and Mathematical Occupations (15-0000); Architecture and Engineering Occupations (17-0000); and Life, Physical and Social Science Occupations (19-0000). Only jobs with at least 100 employees were considered when identifying the highest-paid STEM occupation.

title: Greatest Growth in Jobs for Techies: States
subhead: California, Texas, Virginia post biggest gain in STEM jobs
overview: Bloomberg ranked the U.S. states and the District of Columbia on their increase in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) professionals between 2001 and 2012.
methodology: BLS data were used to identify states with the biggest gains and biggest share of STEM professionals. STEM numbers are aggregated totals of three major occupational groups from Bureau of Labor Statistics Occupational Employment Statistics (BLS OES): Computer and Mathematical Occupations (15-0000); Architecture and Engineering Occupations (17-0000); and Life, Physical and Social Science Occupations (19-0000).
sources: Bureau of Labor Statistics Occupational Employment Statistics

title: Most Efficient: Companies
subhead: PPG, Interpublic among companies that grew profit margins faster than sales
overview: Bloomberg ranked S&P 1500 companies on their ratio of margin growth to sales growth.
methodology: To be included, companies had to have positive sales and profit margins and positive sales and profit margin growth for the last five years. Companies with sales or margin growth rates of less than 1 or greater than 100 were excluded. In addition, profit margin growth had to be greater than sales growth. Growth was calculated using the least squares method from the latest available five years of data. All data were for companies' 2008 to 2012 fiscal years, except for Finish Line, Home Depot and Williams-Sonoma, which were ranked on their 2009 to 2013 fiscal years.

title: Fastest-Growing: College Endowments
subhead: Public universities show the greatest three-year increase in endowment value
overview: Bloomberg ranked colleges and universities on their three-year average annual growth in endowments
methodology: Colleges and universities with endowments of at least $1 billion in their 2012 fiscal year and with at least four years of endowment data were included. Changes reflect withdrawals, management and investment fees, gifts and other contributions, and investment gains and losses. The three-year average annual growth rate was calculated using the least-squares method. The endowment market value data for Canadian institutions were expressed in U.S. dollars. The Texas A&M University System & Foundations total included endowment assets from Texas A&M Foundation and Baylor Oral Health Foundation. The University of Minnesota & Foundations total included combined endowment assets for the Regents of the University of Minnesota, University of Minnesota Foundation and Minnesota Medical Foundation. The total for the University of Illinois & Foundation included the combined assets from University of Illinois and the University of Illinois Foundation.

title: Highest Electricity Production: Countries
subhead: United States leads the world in electricity production with China a close second
overview: Bloomberg ranked countries on their total electricity production, and calculated the percentage of total production attributable to each power source.
methodology: Renewable refers to electricity production from  geothermal, solar, tides, wind, biomass and biofuels, excluding hydroelectric.

title: Fewest Female Top Executives: States
subhead: Deep South is devoid of female executives
overview: Bloomberg ranked the U.S. states and the District of Columbia on the percentage of female workers employed as top executives in 2011.
methodology: Year-round and full-time male and female civilian workers 16 years of age and older were considered. Top executives include chief executives, general and operations managers and legislators.
sources: U.S. Census 2011 American Community Survey 3-Year Estimates

title: Most Volunteers: States
subhead: Utah and Idaho have the highest volunteer rates in the U.S.
overview: Bloomberg ranked the U.S. states and the District of Columbia on the volunteer rates of their residents in 2011.
methodology: The volunteer rate was estimated from the survey population based on the latest U.S. Census data. The rate was calculated as the percentage of respondents 16 or older who performed unpaid volunteer activities through or for an organization during the 12-month survey year. The value of volunteering was calculated by multiplying the estimated value of a volunteer hour, $21.79, according to Volunteering and Civic Life in America, by the total number of volunteer hours for each state.
sources: Volunteering and Civic Life in America (volunteeringinamerica.gov)

title: Greatest Growth in Coal Production: States
subhead: Western states' change in coal production has outpaced that of Appalachian states
overview: Bloomberg ranked the U.S. states on change in coal production from 1987 to 2012.
methodology: Included were states that produced at least 10 million short tons of coal in 2012.

title: Priciest Places to Wed: U.S. Cities
subhead: Manhattan weddings, already the costliest in the U.S., are getting even more expensive
overview: Bloomberg ranked U.S. places on the increase in the average wedding budget from 2011 to 2012.
methodology: The universe was limited to the 20 costliest places in the U.S. for weddings in 2012. Northern California was included in 2011 data for San Francisco.
sources: The Knot, Inc. Real Weddings Survey

title: Biggest Increase in Number of Brewers: States
subhead: California boasts both the highest number of brewers and the biggest increase since 2011
overview: Bloomberg ranked the U.S. states and the District of Columbia on the increase in number of permitted brewers from 2011 to 2012.
methodology: Permitted brewers refer to manufacturers that have completed the appropriate paperwork and obtained the necessary permits to operate though they may not be fully operational yet.
sources: Beer Institute, Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau

title: Greatest Concentration of Senior Poverty: States
subhead: Ninety-five percent of North Dakotans living in poverty are 65 or older
overview: Bloomberg ranked the U.S. states and the District of Columbia on their concentration of senior poverty.
methodology: Three equally weighted criteria were used to create this ranking: the number of seniors (ages 65+) living in poverty as a percentage of the total population living in poverty; senior poverty as a percentage of the working-age (15-64) population; and senior poverty as a percentage of the state's total population. States were ranked in each factor--with 1 indicating the highest percentage of poverty--and  the three ranks were averaged to determine the order.
sources: U.S. Census, Administration on Aging (U.S. Department of Health & Human Services), Measure of America: A Project of the Social Science Research Council, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

title: Longest Retirements: States
subhead: Hawaiians and Minnesotans live longest after retiring
overview: Bloomberg ranked the U.S. states and the District of Columbia on their average life expectancy postretirement.
methodology: "Sunset years" refer to life expectancy postretirement. Sunset years were calculated for each state by subtracting an assumed retirement age of 65 from the average life expectancy for men and women. States were ranked by their gender ratio-weighted average.
sources: U.S. Census; U.S. Department of Health & Human Services' Administration on Aging; Measure of America project of the Social Science Research Council; Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

title: Most Seniors: States
subhead: California has almost 80 times more senior citizens than Alaska
overview: Bloomberg ranked U.S. states and the District of Columbia on the size of their senior (65+) population
methodology: NA
sources: U.S. Census, U.S. Health & Human Services Administration on Aging, Measure of America project of the Social Science Research Council, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

title: Biggest Boomtowns: U.S. Cities
subhead: Austin-Round Rock, TX, shows the best combination of population and GDP growth in U.S.
overview: Bloomberg ranked 360 metropolitan statistical areas (MSAs)  on their  population and real GDP growth from 2007 to 2011, singling out 25 MSAs that showed an increase in both.
methodology: MSAs were ranked on population growth and real GDP compound annual growth and given a corresponding point score of 1 to 100 in each factor. The scores were added together and were divided by the highest possible total to create the score. Included MSAs with at least 1 million residents as of 2011. Census population estimates were as of July 1, 2007, and July 1, 2011.
sources: U.S. Bureau of Economic Analysis, U.S. Census

title: Most Cash After Debt: Companies
subhead: General Electric and Microsoft would be flush with cash even if they paid off their debt
overview: Bloomberg ranked nonfinancial companies in the S&P 500 based on their cash after debt, which is the money they could obtain through cash on hand and securities that could be liquidated quickly, minus their debt.
methodology: Cash after debt was calculated by adding the latest figures for available cash and near-cash items to marketable securities and other short-term investments, then subtracting short- and long-term debt.

title: Most Money Going to Home Improvement: U.S. Cities
subhead: Phoenix homeowners spend the most on home improvement in the U.S.
overview: Bloomberg ranked U.S. cities on average per-owner spending on home improvement.
methodology: The 50 most populous metropolitan areas were considered. Data were from 2011.
sources: Joint Center for Housing Studies of Harvard University

title: Highest Passive Earners: U.S. Cities
subhead: San Francisco, Miami are the best cities to collect income without working
overview: Bloomberg ranked U.S. metropolitan statistical areas (MSAs) on passive income per capita.
methodology: The universe consisted of 51 MSAs with at least 1 million residents. Passive income is personal income from dividends, interest and rent. Per capita income figures were rounded to the nearest dollar.
sources: Bureau of Economic Analysis, U.S. Census ACS 5-Year Estimates

title: Most Noncitizen Homeowners: U.S. Cities
subhead: Texas is the favorite state of homeowners who are not U.S. citizens
overview: Bloomberg ranked U.S. cities based on the percentage of noncitizen homeowners.
methodology: The percentage of total occupied housing units that were owner-occupied by foreign-born, non-U.S. citizens was calculated for each city. Only cities with at least 500,000 residents as of 2011 were included.

title: Highest-Earning Top 5%: U.S. Cities
subhead: Which place has the top-earning top 5%? Try Huntleigh, Missouri
overview: Bloomberg ranked places with the highest income based on the average earnings of the top 5 percent of households.
methodology: Census data were used to identify the 25 places in the U.S. with the highest incomes for the top 5 percent of earners.
sources: U.S. Census American Community Survey Briefs, 11-23, "The Geographic Concentration of High-Income Households: 2007-2011"; 2007-2011 American Community Survey 5-Year Estimates

title: Most Million-Dollar Tax Filers: States
subhead: California still has most million-dollar taxpayers though numbers are decreasing
overview: Bloomberg ranked the U.S. states and the District of Columbia on the number of federal individual tax returns with adjusted gross incomes of $1 million on more.
methodology: Numbers were compared with 2000 and the difference in each state's share of $1 million filers was calculated.. Percentages were rounded.

title: Biggest Gender Gap in Earnings: Countries
subhead: American men earn 23% more than American women--and it's even worse for women in Asia
overview: Bloomberg ranked countries based on their gender pay gap.
methodology: U.S. figures are for full-time, year-round workers ages 15 and older. Eurostat provided data for EU countries. Switzerland and Norway figures are for male and female paid employees working in industry, construction and services jobs (excluding public administration, defense and compulsory social security jobs). Data for remaining countries came from the OECD and are calculated as the difference between median earnings of men and women relative to median earnings of men. All data were the latest available.
sources: Eurostat, Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, United States Census

title: Best Five-Year Employee Growth: Industries
subhead: Tech-related industries have highest five-year employee growth
overview: Bloomberg ranked industries based on employee growth during the last five years.
methodology: Using the last six years of annual employee data, Bloomberg applied the least-squares method to calculate five-year average annual growth in employment for all industry groups in the S&P 500. Most current data were used for the final year. Only groups with five or more companies were included.

title: Highest Male/Female Ratios: States
subhead: North Dakota has the highest male/female ratio for ages 25-34
overview: Bloomberg ranked the U.S. states and the District of Columbia on the male-to-female ratios in the 25-34 age-group dating pool.
methodology: Ratios were calculated by dividing the number of men ages 25-34 in each state who never married or are separated, widowed or divorced, by the number of women who meet those criteria.
sources: U.S. Census Bureau, 2011 American Community Survey

title: Oldest Fleets: Airlines
subhead: Low-cost Allegiant Air has the oldest fleet of all major airlines
overview: Bloomberg ranked airline fleets based on age.
methodology: Public airlines with market capitalizations of at least $1 billion were considered. Air France and KLM were ranked separately, as were Avianca and Taca. Each pair of airlines operates under the same company. Averages included both passenger and cargo planes, except for Singapore Airlines and Lufthansa, which included only passenger planes. Although AMR Corp. had a market cap of $510 million as of December 31, 2012, and wasn't included, American Airlines' fleet averaged 16.6 years and American Eagle Airlines' fleet averaged 9.6 years.

title: Largest Wage Increases: States
subhead: Average pay increased most in D.C. from 2001 to 2011, least in Michigan
overview: Bloomberg ranked the U.S. states and the District of Columbia on their annualized increase in average wages from 2001 to 2011.
methodology: Bloomberg reviewed state cross-industry estimate tables from 2001 to 2011, extracting the annual mean wage figure representing all occupations for each state. The national U.S. average was calculated and set at 100 as of 2001. Then changes were calculated for each year adjusted for inflation. (The average annualized increase for wages nationally was 2.89%.) Included were wage data for 23 major occupational groups and more than 821 detailed occupational titles. Self-employed persons were excluded.
sources: Bureau of Labor Statistics' Occupational Employment Statistics; International Monetary Fund

title: Most Popular for Heating U.S. Homes: Energy Sources
subhead: Gas trumps electricity for heating American homes with solar-energy users scarce
overview: Bloomberg ranked the U.S. states and the District of Columbia on fuel usage in 2011.
methodology: Heating-fuel data were analyzed for each state and the District of Columbia. The states were ranked by the percentage of total occupied housing units that used each fuel type in 2011.
sources: U.S. Census 2011 American Community Survey 5-year Estimates

title: Most Volunteers: U.S. Cities
subhead: Minneapolis-St. Paul-Bloomington has the highest percentage of volunteers
overview: Bloomberg ranked metropolitan statistical areas (MSAs) on citizens' volunteer rates.
methodology: Based on the latest census data, the volunteer rate is the percentage of respondents 16 or older who participated in unpaid volunteer activities through or for an organization at any point during the 12-month survey year. The value of volunteering was calculated by multiplying $21.79-- the estimated value of a volunteer hour, according to Volunteering and Civic Life in America--by the total number of volunteer hours for each MSA. N/A indicates that the sample size was too small to generate reliable statistics for that measure.
sources: Volunteering and Civic Life in America (volunteeringinamerica.gov)

title: Biggest Lottery Losers: States
subhead: Georgia, Massachusetts, New York home to biggest lottery losers
overview: Bloomberg ranked the U.S. states based on the per capita percentage of income lost on lottery tickets.
methodology: The Sucker Score was calculated by subtracting the total dollar amount of prizes awarded in each state from the total dollar amount of ticket sales. The difference was divided by the total personal income of the state's residents and the resulting number was multiplied by 10,000. A higher score indicates a greater propensity for "suckerdom." Lower prize payout and/or higher per capita spending on loterry tickets lead to a higher Sucker Score. All data were from 2010 and did not include video lottery games. Alabama, Alaska, Hawaii, Mississippi, Nevada, Utah and Wyoming were excluded because they do not have state lotteries.
sources: U.S. Census 2010, Bureau of Economic Analysis, Fiscal Year 2010 Annual Reports of state lottery commissions

title: Biggest Brain Gains: U.S. Cities
subhead: Jersey City and Atlanta have shown the biggest increases in educated adults
overview: Bloomberg ranked cities with at least 100,000 residents as of 2011 on the increase in the percentage of the population with a bachelor's degree or higher between 2000 and 2011.
methodology: Among 151 cities that were analyzed, the 20 showing the greatest percentage-point increase in educated adults are shown.

title: Most Stores per Square Mile: States
subhead: New Jersey has 1.4 stores per square mile, more than any other state.
overview: Bloomberg ranked U.S. states on the number of retail establishments per square mile.
methodology: Included were retail establishments from the following NAICS (North American Classification System) titles: electronics and appliance stores, clothing and clothing accessory stores, jewelry stores, sporting goods stores, hobby, toy and game stores, bookstores, department stores and gift, novelty and souvenir stores. Only stores with paid employees were included.

title: Heaviest Women: Countries
subhead: Egyptian women are heaviest in the world
overview: Bloomberg ranked countries on average adult-female weight and calculated the pound-loss necessary to reach the upper level of "normal."
methodology:
Weights were calculated by adapting the standard BMI formula: BMI = (weight in pounds / (height in inches x height in inches)) x 703. 
BMI is an index of weight-to-height used to classify adults as underweight, overweight or obese. Average adult BMI data were collected from the World Health Organization. Sources for average adult height data included OECD Society at a Glance (for OECD and Asia/Pacific countries) and MEASURE DHS, a survey project funded by the U.S. Agency for International Development. To extrapolate 2012 BMI, a simple linear trend was applied to BMI statistics from 1980 to 2008, the most recent data available. Ranking included countries with at least 1.5 million male and female adults and with complete BMI data from 1980 to 2008.
sources: Bloomberg, United Nations Population Division of World Health Organization, OECD Society at a Glance, MEASURE DHS, ICF International, research papers

title: Heaviest Men: Countries
subhead: Czech men are the heaviest in the world
overview: Bloomberg ranked countries on average adult-male weight and calculated the pound-loss necessary to reach the upper level of "normal."
methodology:
Weights were calculated by adapting the standard BMI formula: BMI = (weight in pounds / (height in inches x height in inches)) x 703. 
BMI is an index of weight-to-height used to classify adults as underweight, overweight or obese. Average adult BMI data were collected from the World Health Organization. Sources for average adult height data included OECD Society at a Glance (for OECD and Asia/Pacific countries) and MEASURE DHS, a survey project funded by the U.S. Agency for International Development. To extrapolate 2012 BMI, a simple linear trend was applied to BMI statistics from 1980 to 2008, the most recent data available. Ranking included countries with at least 1.5 million male and female adults and with complete 1980-2008 BMI data.
sources: Bloomberg, United Nations Population Division of World Health Organization, OECD Society at a Glance, MEASURE DHS, ICF International, research papers

title: Busiest Airports for International Travel: U.S. Cities
winner: New York-Northern New Jersey-Long Island, NY-NJ-PA
subhead: New York, Miami and Los Angeles have the most international passengers arriving and departing
overview: Bloomberg ranked U.S. airport hubs based on the number of international passengers that traveled through.
methodology: Includes metropolitan areas with at least 1 million passengers. These passengers must either start or end their journey in the listed U.S. metro area.

title: Heaviest Population: Countries
subhead: U.S. adults outweigh the rest of the world
overview: Bloomberg ranked countries based on the weight of an average adult, which is the gender ratio-weighted aggregate of male and female adults.
methodology:

sources: Bloomberg, United Nations Population Division of World Health Organization, OECD Society at a Glance, MEASURE DHS, ICF International, research papers

title: Greatest Loss of Land: Countries
subhead: The U.S., Japan and Germany are among 26 countries that have been losing land
overview: Bloomberg ranked countries on the percentage of land area lost since 1961.
methodology: Each country's land area circa 1961 was compared with the most recent data available (as of 2010). Countries were ranked by percentage change of land area, from most to least shrinkage. Countries without a coastline were excluded. Current data on land area and coastline were included to give a sense of magnitude of the shrinkage.
sources: World Bank, Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, CIA World Factbook

title: Highest-Paying: College Degrees
subhead: The most lucrative college degrees: engineering, math and science
overview: Bloomberg ranked bachelor's degree fields on the median earnings of workers.
methodology: Fifteen majors were ranked on median earnings for full-time, year-round workers ages 25 and older  by field of first bachelor's degree.
sources: U.S. Census ACS Brief - Field of Degree and Earnings by Selected Employment Characteristics 2011, 2011 ACS 3-year Estimates

title: Most Rapidly Aging: Countries
subhead: Senior ranks swell in Europe, catching up with Japan
overview: Bloomberg ranked countries and sovereigns on four measures related to aging.
methodology: Countries and sovereigns with at least 3 million people or at least 10 percent of their population 65 years of age and  and older were ranked on four factors:  speed of aging, both relative and absolute, through approximately one generation (the beginning of the generation proxy was 1981-1984 and the ending was 2007-2011); average annual concentration of seniors from 2007 to 2011; pipeline of seniors as of 2010 (most recent data available); and number of seniors not participating in the labor force as a percentage of the age 15-64 working population (using latest figures). Their average rank determined the order. Only countries with data for all four factors were included.
sources: United Nations Population Division, International Labor Organization

title: Longest Retirements: Countries
subhead: Singaporeans live 23 years after retirement, Americans just 12
overview: Bloomberg ranked countries based on their average life expectancy postretirement.
methodology: "Sunset years" refer to life expectancy postretirement. Sunset years for men and women were calculated by subtracting retirement age from life expectancy in each country. The average statutory pensionable age and average statutory retirement age in the private sector were used as proxies. The overall global sunset index for each country was created by weighting the sunset years with each country's gender ratio for the 65+ population. Only countries with at least 3 million 65+ residents or 10 percent of the population age 65+ were included.
sources: United Nations Population Division, Social Security Administration; World Bank

title: Most Recession-Resistant: U.S. Cities
subhead: Bismarck, ND, is America's most recession-resistant city
overview: Bloomberg ranked U.S. cities based on their resistance to the economic slowdown between 2007 and 2011.
methodology: Bloomberg analyzed 217 metropolitan statistical areas (MSAs), singling out those with an annual average unemployment rate less than the national rate for 2007 through 2011, median household incomes higher than the national average as of 2011, and increases in both median household income and home prices from 2007 to 2011. These MSAs were then ranked on unemployment rates for each year, the percentage change in home prices from 2007-2011 and the percentage change in median household income from 2007-2011. Each rank received a corresponding point score from 1 to 100. The seven ranks were added together and divided by the highest possible total to create the score. Housing price data included purchase and refinance mortgages for single-family detached properties with conventional conforming mortgage transactions obtained from the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation and the Federal National Mortgage Association. Housing data for Dallas-Fort Worth-Arlington were averaged based on data for Dallas-Plano-Irving, TX and Fort Worth-Arlington, TX.
sources: Bureau of Labor Statistics, Federal Housing Finance Agency, U.S. Census 2011 ACS 1-Year Estimates, U.S. Census 2007 ACS 1-Year Estimates

title: Highest Premiums for Advanced Degrees: U.S. Cities
subhead: Miami offers the greatest increase in pay for workers with graduate or professional degrees
overview: Bloomberg ranked major U.S. cities on the difference in median earnings between workers with only a bachelor's degree and those with a graduate or professional degree.
methodology: The 2011 median earnings of workers with a bachelor's degree were compared with the 2011 median earnings of workers with a graduate or professional degree in 61 cities with at least 300,000 residents as of 2010. Included were workers 25 years old and older.

title: Most Popular in the World: U.S. Fast-Food Brands
subhead: Subway is the world's most popular fast-food establishment. KFC rules in emerging markets
overview: Bloomberg ranked fast-food companies based on total number of establishments.
methodology: The number of fast-food stores were collected for the following brands: KFC, McDonald's, Burger King, Wendy's, Popeyes, Pizza Hut, Taco Bell, Domino's Pizza, Papa John's, Quiznos, Subway, Starbucks, Dunkin' Donuts, Baskin-Robbins, Haagen-Dazs, Dairy Queen, Krispy Kreme and Auntie Anne's.  For this ranking, global emerging consumer markets were defined as countries with more than $2,000 GDP per capita, 2 percent GDP growth and 2 percent household-consumption growth, all using rounded averages from 2000 to 2010. Excluded were countries with populations of fewer than 5 million as of 2010, countries classified as developed by either the FTSE or MSCI and countries with fewer than a total of 50 of the stores considered.  Data were latest available.
sources: Bloomberg, companies, World Bank, International Monetary Fund

title: Worst Dental Health: States
subhead: Over one-quarter of Mississippi seniors have no natural teeth
overview: Bloomberg ranked the U.S. states and the District of Columbia on their dental health.
methodology: Three criteria were equally weighted to create this ranking: the percentage of population living in a dental Health Professional Shortage Area (HPSA); the percentage of adults age 18+ who visited a dentist in the past year; and the percentage of adults 65+ who lost all their natural teeth to tooth decay or gum disease. For each variable, the state with the best dental-health measures received 0 points while the state with the worst received 33.3 points. Remaining states were given points proportional to where they fell between the best and worst. Points were summed to derive each state's dental health score, which has a range of 0-100, a higher score indicating worse dental health.
sources: Kaiser Family Foundation, U.S. Department of Health and Human Services
